review: I can't feel my legs.
game-hours: 45.5
review: I guess......
game-hours: 1002.0
review: Dota 2 is a masterpiece of competitive gaming. Endlessly replayable due to its incredible depth, the game truly never gets old. Continuous support ensures that the game never gets stale, with a constantly changing meta. Dota 2 has a steep learning curve, but once you find your way, there is no other game like it. Few games are as painful to lose, but inversely, as satisfying to win, as Dota 2. Unparalled strategic and mechanical depth ensure that no player will ever be as good as they can be in any one game, yet it is incredibly satisfying to strive for perfection through continued play. Strategy is deeply involved before you even "begin" the game, with hero selection, all the way through to the end of the match. Certain heroes work particularly well against others, are weak to others, and coordinate exceptionally with others. This is due to the array of unique abilities that each hero possesses, and the role they fill on their team. Once the game begins, players must coordinate with their team members in order to play most effectively. This is done in combat, as well as in what item purchases players decide to make. Strategy is extensively involved in item purchases, combat, and positioning. Players must constantly react to the game in order to play effectively, and since no game is ever the same, the experience is always different, making each game a fresh experience, and one that I will continue to enjoy for as long as I can foresee.

game-hours: 1172.6
review: Dota 2 is a multiplayer online battle arena (MOBA) video game and the stand-alone sequel to the Defense of the Ancients (DotA) mod. Developed by Valve Corporation, the game was officially released on July 9, 2013 as a free-to-play title for Microsoft Windows, concluding a beta testing phase that began in 2011. OS X and Linux versions of Dota 2 were released on July 18, 2013. In most regions, Dota 2 is exclusively available through Valve's content delivery platform, Steam. Each match of Dota 2 is independent and involves two teams, both containing five players and each occupying a stronghold at either end of the map. Located in each stronghold is a building called the "Ancient"; to win, a team must destroy the enemy's Ancient. Each player controls a "Hero" character and focuses on leveling up, collecting gold, acquiring items and fighting against the other team to achieve victory.

There is not a single game without at least one Russian talking sh!t in his f#cked-up language, no matter which server are you playing on. The percentage of deserved punishments of all the players getting punished by the auto punish report system must be less than 10%. How reports are planned to be used in Dota2: -This guy intentionally ruins the game for the other players, REPORT. -This guy flames and insults other players and is very unpleasant to play with, REPORT. How reports are ACTUALLY used in Dota2: -This guy doesn't play this hero the way i do, lol, he is noob, REPORT. -This guy doesn't know russian language, REPORT  BLYAD. -This guy told me what to do, i dont like him, REPORT. -This guy died for first blood, what a feeder, REPORT. -This guy just killed me, i dont like him, REPORT. A while ago developers added "ranked" matchmaking to Dota 2. I've been waiting 2 years for this moment, hoping that when ranked is here it would separate bad players from good players and i would finally get to play with some players that are on my level. COMPLETE OPPOSITE! That so called "ranked" matchmaking is so much worse than the regular bad matchmaking. First of all, this is not even a real ranked system. It has no ranks. Skill is "measured" in numbers. Second - i don't even know why they add a ranked system anyway when it matches people that are rank 4000+ with people that are rank 3500. They couldnt even get it to match ranks close to one another. They even removed the solo que option, so basically you go solo, you play with other solos vs a stacked party enemy, and if thats not enough - the solo teammates you get are 10 times worse than the ones you used to get in normal matchmaking. Getting matched with all kinds of noobs, trolls and sh!t. Playing this game solo is worse than aids and cancer combined! The community is so good that when you disconnect in a game, where you play very good and your team is winning, the enemy team starts unpausing the game for you to get the abandon just that so they can increase their chance of winning or leave the game.

game-hours: 318.7
review: When you first start to play Dota 2, it becomes kind of annoying to figure out how to play and what to do. After a few matches, you get frustrated and stop, mostly because of the long game times. You come back to it after 2 or 3 days, and you know what the game is about and have a brief idea on how to play it. After some games, its not as frustrating than when you first started. You continue to play for some weeks afterwards, and decide to abandon a match, due to whatever may be the reason - lag, bad hero, didn't win, etc. You realise that there is a low-priority pool, and have to play in it for 2-4 matches. You get annoyed again when you see that you don't receive points to level up due to low-priority. Nevertheless, you finish your matches and continue. In one match, you get abused for doing a wrong move, or just playing badly, and get annoyed once again from the other player. This continues for some time. By 1 -2 months, you start playing a lot better and aren't as afraid to chat to your team - and if necessary, the other team. After more time, you seem to be great at it, but then you lose the nest 10 games. Anger hits you, from the losses of game after game after game, and suddenly you win. You are now a great Dota player, with all the skills required to play perfectly - well at least almost perfectly, apart from the mishaps every now and then. One of the best games I've played.

review: If you want to play a moba game other then League of Legends, then you should wait no longer. Dota 2 is an excellent moba game with alot of exciting events. You are eligible to find items after you finished a game. You can find items like chests, couriers, hero gear/weapons and much more. There is also a ingame shop where you can buy cosmetic items, but this is optional.

review: Hearing about this back when I was still in highschool playing DotA made me very excited. Immediately signing up for the beta. It took longer than one may expect to get a beta key. I got in around the time Invoker was released which is actually perfect timing since I was still honing my skills with him. For a gamer who spent a lot of time in the first game, It wasn't too hard getting into this game. The feeling is there, the looks of the heroes are very similar which is good since going too far from the original concept might be a bad idea. I have invested a lot of time in this since the day I got my beta key. There are two things that worries me first being that the cosmetics shop might get too fancy for a game like this. I fear the day that we get to see them selling a panda outfit for Pudge or a candy cane for Rylai. game-hours: 1172.4
review: It was when I got rejected when I started playing DotA Allstars in Warcraft III, I was hooked to it. I spent 12 - 14 hours playing it every day. I started to get bored by it and day after day, I didn't feel like playing anymore. When Dota 2 was announced, I wanted to get the beta key... but I didn't, and since I didn't feel like playing the original, I spent maybe a year without it. A friend gave me a key to Dota 2, I installed it and played it once, it was my first time getting wrecked so bad that I didn't have the urge to play another game It was then someone broke my heart, I have never been so down in my life. I took so many antidepressants and peer to peer meetings, but nothing works. One day, that same friend who gave me the key, invited me to play. We won and suddenly I felt better. I played and I played a lot. And every game made me feel better about myself and my perspective in life. Dota 2 was there for me when life was too twisted, when reality was too painful to bear. No matter how much I got rejected and how many times I felt alone, Dota was there, to make me happy and make me feel better. Good things has to come to an end so that better things can start, that was when I met her. She fixed the hole in my heart and stitched up the wreckage of the past. For weeks, I played Dota less and less. Right now, I gave all my stuff to my friend that gave me the beta key, a gift of gratitude if you will. So long Dota and thanks for being there for me when I was down and when I want to escape reality 10/10

game-hours: 37.2

game-hours: 43.8
review: This is an excellent game. For Warcraft 3 lovers, who have played the original DOTA, this will blow you away. There have been a lot of improvements to the overall gameplay, balancing, item modification, hero selection, and overall purpose to the game. For players new to DOTA, not only is this game free to play, (with some purchasable items in game that have no effect on the outcome of the game, just cosmetics), but it is very easily learned, a lot of fun, and it is a game that can be played in about 45 minute intervals. The DOTA Profile is also a great feature, leveling you up as you gain experience so you can be matched with players that are relatively the same skill level you are. It also includes some fun information, like who your most successful heroes were, your win/loss record, and items that you want to feature. Coaching/Spectating is a great new feature from the original DOTA Warcraft 3 Map, because you can have experienced players come in and watch you play, coaching you. You can set it to where you can only listen to that person and no one else, providing personalized instruction. Hero Build/ Item Build is awesome, you can literally create customized builds for your heroes that can be used through the entire steam community. If you're learning a hero you've never played, selecting a community build is a great way to learn. There are many other features, and many other reasons to give the game a try. Whether your an old hat at DOTA, or looking for a change of pace, this game is for you.

review: When I first played the game, I was confused and didnt understand the strategy behind MOBAs. Frustrated, I quit the game for a year. But I came back to try again, I learned from my mistakes and took in some advice, along with watching a few videos on the basics of the game. Once I had a grasp of it and knew what I was doing I began to enjoy the game MUCH MUCH more. The game has great Lore, simple controls, and an easy-to-use shop. This game is also truly F2P, yes, you can buy items from the market that use actual real-world money, but these items are PURELY cosmetic, and do not give you an advantage whatsoever. Most of these cosmetic items can be earned by simply playing the game, which in my opinion makes it truly F2P. This game also has excellent Steam integration, with free guides to help you learn the game. In short, this is a fantastic game that I intend to spend many more hours playing. I fully recommend this title to gamers of all skill levels.

game-hours: 2346.7
review: Dota 2 is a game about social criticism. There are many different valuable classes needed to survive the coming battles, but of course, everyone is tempted to just opt for the top 1%. If there is indeed a working class, it will nearly starve, barely able to afford even basic necessities like boots, in order to sustain the greed of the upper class. There is, of course, a middle class, which is basically just failing to keep up with the upper class while scared  to end up like the lower class. All of this is happening in the vanguard of a great big war that is allegedly happening because the two factions like different tree colors, but it's really to make more money to buy more stuff that allows you to wage more war to make more money. The emulated class system is supported by severe language barriers and the game does a good job of making you hate even your closest friends, eventually. 10/10.

game-hours: 561.4
review: Two teams of five fight across three lanes. Three specific types of shop sell sixty different magical items. There are more than a hundred characters to play, and an unknown quantity still to come. Eight types of specific role that you can play as part of your team. Its safe to say that Dota 2 is a game of numbers. Despite Valves best efforts to ease players in gently, Dota 2 is an inherently overwhelming game. The first few hours of this MOBA are relentlessly bemusing, but after that the difficulty curve becomes smoother - giving you a tangible sense of how youll get better. Each match tends to last somewhere between 30 minutes and an hour, offering vast amounts of entertainment if youve got the time. Lengthy games can cause frustration when things arent going well, however, which is the main source of Dota 2s rep for breeding a virulent strain of internet . Losing isnt frustrating if youre learning something new, and getting to know every character will take roughly 100 hours. Its also worth mentioning that you really get to know them - the vocal work and animations are superb, giving Dota 2 some of the best character design in gaming. Over the next 50 hours it becomes clear that Dota 2s complexity isnt pointless PC-RPG-posturing. Every character, skill, and item serves a purpose. Its a pleasant surprise to find that its depth doesnt damage the clarity of the design. Gold buys you items and XP levels characters up, but in contrast to the messy fashion in which the RPG genre has incrementally evolved, Dota 2s purity shines. Whilst too impenetrable to entice non-savvy spectators, theres no doubting the games quality as an E-sport. Youll need knowledge, skill, and a smidge of spider-sense. Friends to learn with are a must, and dont be deceived by the lack of a pricetag: Dota 2 will cost you hundreds of hours.

game-hours: 2453.4
review: So, with nearly 1200 hours on record, I feel like I should share my thoughts. First and foremost, this game will make your family love you less. Your mom, significant other, child, pet etc will need you for something and your response will be, "I can't pause this". You will be accused of putting video games before loved ones because they don't understand that if you retreat to the fountain to kiss your kid goodnight, all of your Russian teammates will yell at and report you. They'll treat you so badly for having a family that the whole match will be ruined and you'll start to hate DOTA. Your family cannot understand that. At its core, DOTA is a team game made up of three kinds of people. People that want to play as a team, Peruvians and Russians. The server you select has no bearing on which of these types you will meet. If you play Captain's Mode or Captain's Draft, you typically avoid the latter two types, but the game is very competitive and unfriendly for new players. Basically, you have to learn to play with idiots. You'll turn into a racist, you'll yell at someone in a language they don't understand, you'll be blamed when your  teammate runs into a 1v5 fight and loses because you should've been there. Eventually, you will become comfortable with a few characters and decide to explore Ranked games or Captain's Mode. You'll be paired with people that speak your language. Games, tactics, and plans will come together. You'll make friends. You'll start to queue together on a nightly basis. You'll form a team. You won't be great, but you'll have fun.... tons of fun. As long as you didn't need that family we talked about earlier. DOTA 2 is an emotional roller coaster that will transform you into a racist and require Zoloft. 10/10

game-hours: 1794.2
review: Most people on steam have probably heard the name of this game countless times now. So let me give you a short and simple review on it. Get it. Now that that's out of the way try and use the tips I am about to give you so you can get he best possible experience that this game has to offer. Dota 2 has a steep learning curve meaning you can't just jump in there and expect to know what you are doing. When you first launch the game as of recently you are taught how to play through the tutorial the game has to offer. Actually pay attention to this or it will bite you in the  when you are actually playing. Once you get that over with you're probably going to say to yourself "Ok I think I get what I am doing, let me play online matchmaking" Here's one simple answer for you; NO. Dota 2 requires a team effort, and what I mean by a team effort is that if 1 person does something it will affect the team. If 1 person does bad, the team will take the toll of that 1 person. So if you are going straight into matchmaking with almost no experience, you are most likely going to die a lot, get yelled at, close the game, and never come back. Trust me I should know because that was my first experience with Dota 2. Now what I do recommend you do is either practice by yourself or with friends in an offline bot match. That way if you do bad you don't feel bad for perhaps costing the team the game. Not only is this better, as you keep playing you will learn more and more about the game. Try and find someone that is experienced to help you understand the game and help you progress in skill for it. Once you feel that you are more knowledgeable about the game you can go ahead and do perhaps coop bot and then onto the traditional matchmaking where it is 5v5 team fights. Dota 2 is one my favorite games to date. The fact that I have this gem another chance makes me lucky. Try to follow the tips I provided in this recommendation and I guarantee you that you will not be dissappointed with Dota 2.

game-hours: 823.8
review: An evolution of the Defense of the Ancients (a spin off from Warcraft 3). It has the signiture and feel of its predicesor with a much added kick in graphics and almost everything else. The game tries its best to branch out from its older version and I must say, it is succeding with every step it makes. The biggest thing though which separates it greatly from the the old DOTA is the market place and the punishment system, which punishes players for leaving the game unfinished and for being rude to other players. It is this system which separates and cements this game into something of a higher level. The only downside is that you need a gaming computer with high end specs in order to enjoy the game 100 percent. While most first world country won't have any problems with this, players living in third world countries might have an unfair disadvantage when playing online. Overall, the game raises the bar for other games out there in this genre.

game-hours: 268.0
review: Dota 2 can be tough to get into depending on personal play style, which heroes you start off trying -- took me about a week to find my primary due to the boatloads of heroes available -- and the skill of those you get paired with when you're not playing with friends. It is so very worth it, though. When you're playing a hero you're comfortable with alongside a few good allies even a loss can be exhilaratingly fun as you force your enemy to earn their victory. And of course winning certainly isn't half bad, either. While the nuances of the heroes and whom plays best against whom and where may take a while to sort out, however, the base game is simple to learn. --Runs great even on a laptop. --All heroes playable from the start with new ones added all the time. --Multiple game types provide variety. Tired of the standard "all pick"? Try randomly assigned heroes. Or give "least played" mode a whirl and watch the mayhem play out as you and nine other people all try to play heroes that you don't have the first clue how to use. Prepare to see lots of "oops" and "oh, so THAT's what that does". And "sorry". So, so much "sorry". --Great graphics (especially for the genre). --Music, sound effects and voices get high marks. --Paid items have no effect on gameplay beyond the purely cosmetic. --Pretty much anything that you can buy can be earned for free (at random) from simply playing the game or can be trade for with other players. --Custom huds and announcers can be bought, randomly received after games or traded for to tailor the look and sound of your game to your tastes. What's more, they're shared during matches; If one person in the match owns a given hud or announcer then EVERY person in the match will have access to it for that game. It's not unusual to see nearly a dozen available during a game. --Special holiday game types are always a lot of fun and the developers aren't afraid to really shake things up for them, even adding new ingame items and altering hero abilities. Of course standard matches are still available during these times. --Updates, while very frequent, are usually so small that they rarely take longer than five minutes at most to complete.

game-hours: 492.5
review: A very good game, excellent graphics.
game-hours: 2319.6
review: DOTA 2 was my first introduction to the MOBA genre and I have to say it can be very addicting. Games like Starcraft scared me away from 4X RTS games because of the level of micro-management it requiremed, so I was a bit hesitant to play this game. DOTA 2 however has little to no micro-management depending on the heroes you choose. It provides a wide variety of different play styles for different player preferences. Later I heard about Heroes of Newerth and League of Legends, so I thought I'd try them out. I played a couple games of LOL and knew that it just didn't provide the depth of gameplay I got playing DOTA 2. I quickly uninstalled it. Heroes of Newerth provides the same depth I would say, but the experience just didn't feel as smooth as DOTA 2. Maybe it had something to do with the pacing of the game. After uninstalling HoN, I've never looked back. DOTA 2 is here to stay. I highly recommend playing this game. It's quite fun if you spend a little time to get into it. My advice is to take it slow, learn how to play, and expect to fail a lot in the beginning. Remember, you can't get better at DOTA 2, you can only suck less.

game-hours: 2219.7
review: What point is there in recommending a free to play game? An interested reader can now simply download the game and dispense with the opinions of stranger. Of course, Dota 2 is not the only game that is free to play, and the genre is rather notorious for its steep learning curve, so this recommendation is intended to answer a a slightly different question: is it worth the time? Largely, yes, but maybe it's better to consider some of the features that might turn the curious player into a fan of the game or not. The process of learning can be rewarding in and of itself. Valve has put a lot of work into breaking down the learning curve into managable pieces, though it is by no means complete. Perhaps the best analogy is with chess: The tutorials and bots will teach you the mechanics of the game, but this only accounts for a very small part of what we generally consider 'knowing chess/Dota'. Of course, much like in Chess, the community has provided guidance and past games to study and consider on the path to mastery. Furthermore, in the relatively brief period of time I have played the game, there have been substantial changes to heroes and the map itself, meaning that the game continues to provide rewards for thinking on your feet instead of rote memorization. This is not to say that certain 'core builds' are irrelevant (they're important, and you can set them up as presets in the game itself or simply use someone else's), only that there are great rewards to be found in understanding *why* those builds are important. For what it is worth, I have found the guides produced by Purge to be a great introduction to thinking about the game, and his conduct during games (usually) serves as a model that the community would do well to follow. Which brings me to the first major stumbling point of Dota. Despite tremendous efforts on Valve's part to keep the toxic elements of the Dota community to a minimum: you will play with extremely unpleasant people who will not make the game fun. There are number of ways this can happen. People can simply have terrible attitudes and do their best to make you feel awful. Put them on mute immediately. But once you get past the initial stages of learning, you'll develop a certain sophistication for play style. I cannot think of a game that has teamwork as a more essential component to it. Games played with strangers are not assured to have the expected level of cohesion and, at low skill levels such as mine, the chances of the mythical 'ideal game of Dota' are vanishingly small. The problem is that this is simply not a matter of 'other people.' You will ruin games for people through not being prepared, or having an off day. You may also find yourself becoming short tempered, or hostile to your teammates due to the frustration of the game. It is uncomfortable to admit how many chat messages have been started in anger, only to be shortly abandoned after a moment's reflection. This could explain the challenge of the Dota community's attitude, but, whatever the causes, it is a factor that an aspiring player will need to deal with. There will be a point where the bots cease to be fun to play against. At that point you will begin playing with people. At that point you will have lots of bad games for reasons of attitude, team composition, or all of the above. *BUT* the games that are good pay off so much more than all those challenges combined and magnified. Even in the dregs of pub games, to hit that magical team that just clicks without needing to be told the basics, or doesn't go for selfish picks in hero selection, is an absolute joy that anyone should get to experience at least once before throwing in the towel. There are incremental rewards as well: being able to view some of your old replays and see how far you've come. Supporting so well that weak carry was still able to snowball and win. Even the realization that, by instinct, you made a tactical decision that meant the difference between an escape or a death, all these things put a little wind in the sails and motivate continued time in the game. Finally, being a Dota player has opened me up into new avenues of entertainment that I simply didn't appreciate before. With events such as The International I can see this game played at the highest skill levels. I finally have a toe hold into being able to appreciate the interest in eSports. More importantly, as a player of the game, I can appreicate the skill in those games to a much greater degree than any other spectator sport. Despite the vast gulf of knowledge and talent between myself (and most players) and professionals, I feel like playing Dota gives me a better understanding of the decisions and plays that are being made in high skilled games, than a better knowledge of skating or puck handling would give me of a professional hockey game. The dynamics of the skill levels are entirely different, but Dota 2 will always have the same mechanics for everyone and the same map, meaning you have the exact same resources (human capital aside) at your disposal as the pros do. In essence, this is only a game I could recommend to someone who was willing to put in the time, tough out the hard times (and there will be hard times. I write this during a time where I'm particularily frustrated with the game and partly to answer the question why I bother for *myself*), and who genuinely finds enjoyment in the process of learning. There is absolutely no shame in not wanting to take up a game that asks this kind of commitment, and the claims of how 'hardcore' a gamer is usually boil down to an individual trying to assert their preferences over the greater population. If you don't have the time, if you don't feel particularily thick skinned, if you don't like the idea of 'working' at a game, then I do not recommend Dota 2. But for those who find value in the journey, fire up the download and start playing.

review: Dota 2 is a low pace MOBAs at the beginning of the game, and progresses on to a faster pace haveing you know that you can get killed by a riki at anytime. There are many charaters of dota 2. game-hours: 624.5
review: Pros: With 100ish heroes and a massive range of items this game will keep you playing for hours trying to discover the best combination of items for each hero, the best combinations of complimentary heroes for a team and to uncover stacks of aesthetic items to win. There are different game types to allow for practice with bots, ranked matches for more skilled players and tournaments for full teams who wish to compete. When you get a good team the atmosphere is really good and victories feel like a real achievement. As well as the standard game types there are often updates to bring players seasonal game types such as Frostivus around Christmas. It has a simple interface which makes controlling your character and communicating with other players easy without compromising control of either when multitasking. As for graphics, you can play the game on a very standard computer at low graphics without losing any of the experience and at high graphics it is visually pleasing but just as good. Unlike many other multiplayer games you can only buy aesthetic items from the shop using real world money. This prevents people with stacks of cash boosting themselves to become the best players based on cash and not skill (a common complaint in MMORPGs and other platforms). Cons: As with any massively multiplayer game there are many cons, these mostly revolve around the players. When finding a match you are given the option to set a language preference so you can speak with people who understand you. This function is next to useless. I have played over 300 matches and I'd say only about 100 of those were with a team of people who spoke English well enough (when specifying English in the language preference) to lay out or understand complex tactics. There are designated keys for simple commands to try and overcome the language barrier but this is often not enough for skilled players. Next is the reporting function. While you only receive a penalty for multiple reports, it is often the case that petty people will report you for winning games or simply for killing them. As far as I know these reports are not checked by moderators or not to a high standard because I've been perfectly polite and ended up being thrown in the sin bin (Low priority matchmaking) for having a winning streak. The matchmaking system is highly frustrating, it is not based on skill (some say this is a good thing... but it REALLY isn't) so if you have one bad person on your team it brings the entire team down. The servers are always crashing in some way, shape or form which can continue for days. Finally, there are a great number and variety of people who play DOTA. I'd like to say that most of these people are good natured but I have very often experienced people making comments of a nationalist, racist, biggoted, childish (etc) nature towards other players. Everything from "go and kill yourself" to "I had your Mum last night". It's a keyboard warrior dominated world to say the least. Conclusion: It's a really good game worth hours of fun and defintely worth downloading because it's free (can't complain too much about game/server faults with it being free as they do get fixed). BUT the community are mostly unforgiving, cruel and will flame you if you're not up to par (that's if you can understand what they're saying). If you're unable to ignore people when they're being vicious then get real life friends to join you. Otherwise avoid like the plague as the frustration will give you an aneurism.

game-hours: 1485.6
review: Dota 2 is a MOBA (multiplayer online battle arena) title developed by Valve and Icefrog, the creator of the original Warcraft III mod from which this game was based. Dota plays like a RTS (real time strategy) that pits two teams of five players against each other: each player can choose from a large pool of playable heroes, each with his/her own primary stat, role and gameplay. A match of Dota 2 revolves around both destroying all the enemy buildings, exspecially the huge and sturdy ancient in the very end of each base, and killing off non playable units and other players in order to gain experience to acquire new abilities or improve the ones already gained or the stats and gold to buy powerful pieces of equipment in order to make the various heroes even more deadly Dota 2 is a rather complex videogame: being a successful player involves around having a good knowledge of the various heroes abilities, how to react quickly to various events and how to plan ahead in order not to give the enemy team too much of an advantage. Each match is rather unique and unpredictable, with comebacks being very rare, but possible nevertheless Dota 2 is rather infamous for its playerbase, which is arguably the most rude, angry and elitist wannabe I've ever seen. Expect the other players to quickly point out your mistakes, sput insults and menaces at you for percived errors and get upset at you for not following what each team mate believe you should do at any given second of the match. It's also worth mentioning that the in-game report system that Valve designed in order to isolate the most unbereable members of the community rarely works, and it's instead used by rude players in order to silence or just plain sabotage other players they disagree with. Another great issue is that, while Dota 2 features language specific servers, most players won't join the proper servers, but will instead opt to join all the servers available and get mad at other people if they don't speak their native language. Russians players have become quite infamous for such practice If you can manage to stand tall of all the abuse described above, Dota 2 can reveal itself to be quite the interesting experience and generally a good multiplayer game to play

review: If you're a veteran MOBA player, Dota2 shouldn't be unknown to you. It is the best one out there after all. But if you're new to the genre, Dota 2 is the most beginner friendly MOBA as of right now. It offers practise spacing from walking around, to buying items, to last-hit creeps and destroy towers. When you've learned the basics, you can practise against bots. You can play either with bots or with actual players to practise playing with a team.

game-hours: 1114.6
review: DOTA 2 - The true MOBA Dota finds its origin as a custom map in Blizzards' Warcraft 3. Originally named Dota AllStars, this was the very first full-blown 'MOBA' (even though that term only surfaced with the success of League of Legends, many years later). Having played DOTA since that day, I can safely say that the true spirit of this game has been carefully preserved and refined. In fact, the game has always been treated in the very same way Blizzard would treat its releases of Starcraft and Warcraft: an endless patch process of refinement and rebalancing bordering on true perfection. At this point, DOTA has seen similar games pass by, of which the most notable one has to be League of Legends. However, there are some key differences between the two games, and that will be the focus of the second half of this review. What IS the difference, and how does it affect the game, and the players? - MECHANICS - The first, most noticeable difference between Dota and LoL has to be the way heroes work. Where LoL offers a palette of heroes with many 'spammable' skills and ground targeted skill shots at - generally - low resource costs, Dota forces the player to consider very carefully how and when to use the skills available to him. Especially in the early game, Dota puts the focus on slowly progressing in the lane by taking enemy last hits and is unique in its option to deny friendly units to the enemy team by last hitting those. With that, Dota early laning phases turn out to be a very skillbased game of 'trading blows'. Not through skills, but by simple attacks and smart positioning can players gain the upper hand. There are other aspects of Dota that force the individual player into taking the initiative, coming up with tactics or setting up ambushes. One of these is the map itself: the Dota map can be moved across through relatively cheap teleport scrolls, and it is smaller than the map in LoL, but big enough to provide ample room for surprise attacks. The Dota map is also built more like a Deathmatch map in a first person shooter - there are many paths to escape and ambush. Another aspect is the use and presence of runes, and the 'jungles' along with map-boss Roshan. All of these aspects add to the incredibly awesome metagame, which is where Dota makes LoL and all other variations on the theme pale in comparison. To top off this plethora of tactical choices, Dota team fights are generally fast-paced and can be over in a matter of seconds. Mobility, avoidance, and skillful positioning are just as important as character build and itemization. A player who is far behind, can still win by using terrain and positioning to his advantage. - THE METAGAME - The Metagame (the 'overall playstyle') of Dota is different with every single game you enter. This is where I feel Dota gets to beat LoL any day of the week. LoL is based on feature sets and team makeup. You pick a team that works, and that decides your meta. In essence a game of LoL is quite predictable once the picks are over. Not so in Dota. In Dota, every hero has a nemesis, and players get to see their opponents' picks, which makes hero picking a little game in itself, where players are already forced into tactical choices. Not only is team makeup of importance, but also how well your hero can handle the opposition. Due to this major difference in the metagame, games in Dota can end within the first 20 minutes or take as much as two hours to complete. It all depends on the players and how they choose to play. Similarly, even the same hero can be played in several ways. It is not uncommon to see supporting heroes take on a 'carrying' role, or seeing the initiator heroes turn into tanks. - CONCLUSION - Where LoL relies heavily on the available feature-set and spoonfeeding content (or keeping it behind a paywall) to keep the game interesting, Dota needs none of this. Dota is not only free-to-play, it is a full-blown MOBA with the complete hero roster and all of its functionality available right from the start. Dota can stay Dota and not change a single thing (quite much like it has done the past 10 years...!) and still be a great competitive game 20 years from now. And that is exactly why Dota is unbeatable within this type of games.

game-hours: 698.2
review: This recommendation comes from someone who regularly plays MOBA games, namely this and League of Legends. Short summary here, long review below: Pros: -Very in depth, challenging, complex, yet rewarding -Absolutely no 'pay to win' - All items are purely for cosmetic or other reasons and do not add advantages to gameplay -Very strong matchmaking - Consistently even matches are found. Ratings are separated between normal and ranked too. -Cool tools other MOBA's are lacking in - strong spectactor/replay system, tickets for tournament games, coaching system, intelligent bots with varying difficulty levels, cheats for custom games, crafting/item management. -Thriving competitive scene -Excellent map, sound, art/character and gameplay designs -Variety of modes (different kinds of drafts, all pick, etc.) -Valve economy gives it a huge advantage over other MOBA's - Community workshops allow players to contribute items directly to the game (and benefit), players can sell/trade items. -Flexible character loadouts - you 'mix and match' items instead of having to choose between skins when it comes to customizing heroes. -It's on Steam - again an advantage compared to other MOBA's as this gives access to Steam features on the go, like communication with friends regardless of game being played, stores, personal stuff, etc. Cons: -Steep learning curve and ocassionally hostile community can turn off new players very fast. -Less clarity + more complexity compared to other MOBA's contribute to learning curve -Only one map (variety comes from different modes as opposed to different maps). You'll always be playing 5v5 matches, although this is not really a con unless you get bored of it. For the average player, the actual gameplay between this and its predecessor (a custom map on Warcraft 3) did not significantly change. However, DotA 2 being it's own stand alone game means it is freed from an archaic engine, and in combination with being a Valve game gives it a huge amount of freedom and overhaul. I will refer to DotA 2 as simply DotA. First, DotA's free to play, and unlike other MOBA's, all heroes are free to play (you do not need to grind or purchase them). Valve makes money off this through purely cosmetic means, and this time this is for real. Many other games, even TF2, sell items that CAN make a difference in gameplay. DotA allows a new player to be just as strong as a veteran's account, as it all depends on the players and not grinding/buying things to access things. For those new to the game, DotA can be a very complex MOBA game, at least definitely more than other games like League of Legends (LoL). it is a Multiplayer Online Battle Arena (MOBA), where generally 5v5 matches are played. Each player controls a hero who must level up throughout the match, gaining gold and items to gain more powerful and use teamwork to defeat the opposing team by ultimately destroying their main base. Part of this genre's allure is that each match starts fresh, with everyone having to go through early, mid, and late phases of each match every time. It's all a test of skills rather than who grinded the most. Unlike other MOBA's, It is more punishing, more challenging, harder to master, but the allure comes from the reward of being able to overcome these challenges. DotA is a very time consuming game - expect to spend tons of time learning and being surprised at pretty much everything, because MOBA games in general are difficult. Each match can last for pretty lenghty periods of time too (over 40 minutes I find). That said, I recommend this game if you're up to the challenge. It's very demanding but can be really rewarding once you get the hang of things. I play both LoL and DotA and over time I've found DotA to be much more rewarding and exciting due to this increased depth and challenge. There are tools for new players to help learn, such as recruitment bonuses, a coaching system (where a player can coach players in their party, giving them a spectactor like mode of their teammates so they can issue out private voice, text, and commands, even highlighting things on the student's HUD), and an actual tutorial/training. Even if you're a bit afraid of the community or the challenges of learning the game, I still recommend this game if you can get a friend to help out. This game is exponentionally more enjoyable with friends and it is not as difficult as you think to get the hang of things. Remember, the rewards of overcoming these challenges are much greater than many other games, so give it a try!

review: Great game that is free and extremely fun.
game-hours: 727.3
review: At first Dota 2 was not that engaging, because of the learning curve. Being a new comer to MOBA's in general though it was very helpful to run through the tutorial and the bot matches to get a grasp of what was going on. After you get the hang of it though, it gets highly addictive. There are a lot of possible interactions between abilities, item builds, and hero selection. Having all of the hero's to try out at your leisure is a daunting yet very encouraging option. I love that I can choose any hero, especially if you just want to run a bot match to try them out before playing with people. The community can be harsh, but it can also be very friendly. Making friends on Dota can be easy. They throw quite a few seasonal events which are a lot of fun. I love the art work and hero artistic design. I can't believe that this game is free to play. They do offer quite a few amazing cosmetics, like a portal pack for purchase. You get to hear GlaDos announce the match, which is very entertaining. I highly recommend playing the game and spending time with it. I would say the first 60 hours you play is all learning experience. Consider that you have 107 current heros to play, each hero will take you at least 3 rounds to really get a hang of (not just by yourself, but with your team and hero selections, item builds, etc.) Each round is about 20 - 45 minutes. Which it is a good thing to play with a variety of heros to begin with just to learn what they can do. One last point to mention, the hero's are well balanced. In public games there seems to be defined favorites, but by no means are they over powered. By far this is one of my favorite games.

review: Dota 2 is a real-time strategy game as known as MOBA (Multiplayer-Online-Battle-Arena) You'll need a teamwork to play this game. Every game is the same map with different strategy. It is also the best languages learning game. I'm playing on the SEA server and I learned about 5 languages like Pinoy, Indo, Malay, Chinese, Korean, and sometimes Russian. Imagine when you're trying to pay attention on the game but the chat log is full of their languages. Especially Russian "" always appeared on the chat log. It means BlTCH as well. This game has the mute system which I'm f*ckin' love it. It helps me solve these problems. -Remember no English. Of course if you're new to this game, you'll get a lot of blames. game-hours: 1043.0
review: KAPP
game-hours: 10.1
review: Very simple and Very complicated at the same time. This game gives you opportunity to play special hero-character selected from huge list of heroes. Simple side of the game: - 2 opposite bases. To win you need to capture one. - 5 players Vs 5 players. Empty slot(s) to be played by GameBot. - Pick a hero, push Battle. Thats it. Complicated side of the game. - You need to know Hero you playing and how level him in details. - You need to have at least 1 nonBot friend playing with you to get Win or to resist at random games. - You need to know what duo of heroes is a good hero-combo and what duo is suck hero-combo. - You need to know when/where and what to buy. - You need to know how to read tha map, where to push, where to defend. How and when to do it right. - You need to know how to farm coins and exp fast to get advantage and buy things for yourself at later stage of round. You need to know all above for 100% to get good Win/Loose statictic. And yeah,,,be ready to read a lot of crap from "zombie" players, who lives in Dota 2 for years. For example, i've tryed to play normal match at my very first time and I've read a lot of new thigs abt myself. Even after passing through all training matches/tests and its your first Player vs Player match. Ignore all chat crap & Have fun!

game-hours: 84.2
review: This game is fun, but just not made for me. The mechanics are amazing and the gameplay is good, but just not made for me. I only play this when I am bored or when friends ask for my help, but otherwise I won't. I want to be able to lead an army into victory, not just one hero into death. But, even though I don't like it, it is a really fun game and I recommend it to all that like single-hero strategy games. With a lot of heroes and even more different skills you will have hours of playtime before you even know half of it. Just look at me, nearly 90 hours of in-game time and I only know how to use three heroes (out of lots). This game is certainly amazing and big. The only thing I really don't like is that there only is one map. I want to be able to play on different maps, with different tactics, but nope, only one map. Still a good game, even if you don't pay anything. Talking about paying, for as far as I know you can get anything without paying, it will only take a little longer because you need luck with the drops, but further one you can use the steam marketplace to trade your unused items for money and buy better items from it. So still, why won't I play it? Because it is not my type of game. No other reason.

game-hours: 1777.6
review: Started out playing DotA on the old WC3 engine and I played that for 7+ years before I shifted into Dota 2 with the beta. Dota 2 offers much more than the original WC3 version in terms of graphics and gameplay, as the old engine's hero and skill interactions were hampered by limitations (DotA Allstars was just a custom map). Cosmetics, tournaments, and streaming are all seamlessly integrated; and are constantly being improved at the behest of the community. The game is a bit hard to get into at first, but after you have the basics down, you'll play for an innumerable amount of time. Adding friends into the mix for crazy strategies and plays increases the replayability and enjoyment of the game to another level. One of the best games. EVER.

game-hours: 2550.1
review: Dota 2 is a sequel to the Defense of the Ancients (DotA) Warcraft III: Reign of Chaos and Warcraft III: The Frozen Throne mod., Developed by Valve Corporation, Designed by none other than IceFrog and distributed by Steam. I was a DotA player previously and shifted to DOTA 2 just before the The International Dota 2 Chamionship 2012, after I got beta invite from Steam. DotA players will love Dota 2 because of IceFrog and his concept and designs and its very similar to DotA but with added attractions and customization. If you have played DotA in your past you can very well know what the game is all about, but if you haven't, don't worry, DOTA 2 has got your back. You get training and how to play and all you need to know In-Game. Its a free to play game, but I think its about time to change that and make people buy this game just because its worth buying. So, what are you thinking? Just download the game and start playing. Make friends and teams online or ask your friends to join alongside yourself. Just Remmeber : Every player you come across in game is there to have fun and enjoy the game like yourself. So, please keep the gaming spirit alive and don't forget to enjoy and have fun. Hope you guys like my review and start playing this game soon. See you all in game.

game-hours: 931.2
review: I've played strategies mostly. MOBA is a different type of game, where you have less to worry about but you have other people to worry for, and coordinate with them. In RTS games you are in control of everything and your opponent is in in control of everything. But here, you have to worry about 4 teammates and 5 opponents. What I like about is is the wide range of heroes to choose and the various ways you can play them, which makes the possibilities limitless. Unlike LoL which I have played for a bit, the graphics are less cartoony and the game rewards skill (denying and not feeding) and punishes you for bad play (enemies snowballing, losing towers, feeding etc.) The only thing I don't like are games taking 40 minutes on average. An sc2 game would take 15-30 mins.

game-hours: 901.1
review: If youre looking for a reason to commit time to Dota 2  if youre actually reading this review for advice and a critical opinion, rather than to see what score Im going to give the most popular game on Steam  then, first up, thanks for being here. Second, I want you to consider what it means when two grown men accidentally lather each other in regenerative goop. Its gamings equivalent of holding a door open for somebody who is already reaching to hold the door open for you: a synchronicity of kindness that speaks to a deeper shared understanding of the situation both people are in. Dota is a game where you can say the words are you thinking what Im thinking? and be reliably assured that the person on the other end of your VoIP connection actually is. It might have the systems and bearing of a videogame, but Dota shares the social impetus of a sport. Its single environment isnt a map, its a pitch.

game-hours: 1591.7
review: I remember, about a year ago I was handed a beta key to this game. I played a few times, although I remember my first game of Dota 2, in bots. I didn't really know what I was doing, however I still enjoyed it. I put it away for a while, and about 3 or 4 months ago I picked the game up again due to fascination for the game yet again. I noticed immense changes, and across the time I have been playing, I noticed more improvements since I started a year ago. All I can honestly praise about the game is the time and dedication put into this game by Valve. If you have ever played a Valve game (TF2, Portal, Half-Life), this game is made with the same quality and care, with over a hundred heroes to play, each have their own amazing model, animations, cosmetics and voice-lines and lore. This game has a somewhat great community (I say somewhat because of the constant game-s who love to ruin my games), and Valve takes input from it. Each hero has their own respective playstyle, such as micro-management, and you can change the way you play with each hero by skilling them different, or building items differently then you normally would, thus creating new ways to play your hero and adjust to each situation. I most definitally recommend this game only because of the infinite enjoyment that this game bears, even if you lose, you can get better and learn from it.

game-hours: 367.9
review: IMO, If you're thinking about league or dota, dota. I'll give the score, but beneath that will be reasons dota's better than the next moba you'll try to pick up. Dota2-9/10 PROS: -Every hero is free, so no real money needed. (except skins) No real money to buy that good champ you want -Good community -Much more rewarding for a skilled player. It's not that other mobas are *easy* but more towards the idea of them taking less focus. -Better graphics and particles (IMO, because some can reason that their bad) -Voice chat, allowing skilled party members to quickly say what they need to say rather than typing -Very balanced. Everything is weak against something else. CONS: -Laggy, at times. -Occasionaly you'll find a toxic player. (very rude) -Much harder to git gud at, due to high experience needed. - oh yeah, and some people stay on the wrong server, despite being spanish, brazillian, russian

review: At first, There is Warcraft 3: Frozen Throne released long time ago. The creator was Blizzard Entertainment, one day they got an idea to make simple-strategy-game-without-story-mode. They make a custom map called Defense of the Ancients, and then they rename it into DotA. The guy who created Dota is a legend, he was IceFrog, Blizzard Entertainment Video Game Designer and now he working for Valve and create Dota 2! And from there DOTA 2 WAS BORN! Dota 2 is a good MOBA game, the graphics was good and detailed, very different from Dota 1. They DO NOT copying it, some heroes Valve change the race, but the heroes is not different. BEST VALVE GAME!!! SECOND WAS TF2, AND THEN CS GO! I salute Valve for making this. Difference: Warlock: In Dota 1 he was an Orc, but now a human Storm Spirit: In Dota 1 he was a Panda, now a human or a spirit. And there are severals other heroes THE SPECIALITIES OF DOTA IS IT'S VERY FUN TO PLAY WITH YOUR FRIENDSS!!! And then heroes are fun to play with. I RECOMMEND THIS FOR THOSE WHO PLAY DOTA 1 or STRATEGY GAMESS! But, I DON'T RECOMMEND THIS FOR THOSE WHO LIKE FPS AND TPS-LIKE GAMESS! 8.9/10 GOOD GAME VALVE!      Y

game-hours: 2046.2
review: Dota is one of my most played game. If you are familiar to MOBA (Multiplayer online battle arena) Dota is a game for you , it is difficult compare to LoL (League of Legends) no doubt on that . Its a true "play to win" game , purchasable items have no affect in gameplay they are only cosmetic for appearance only . All hero are unlocked unlike LoL you got to pay to unlock or play for hours or days to unlock a single champion . Dota matchmaking "Ranked Match Making" is quite broken. People gets quite frustrated if someone feed's or does some kind of mistake . I know it is quite a reasonable reason , as i did too . You wasted your life 40 min and some random people destroyed the match for you and other's . As goes for gameplay Dota is hard and takes time to learn it is a game for people who are patients . Heroes are quite balanced there are some cool events too like Diretide . its a fun game to play with friends and gets quite annoying too when people does stupid mistakes . There are people who likes to teach noob's like Purge one of my idol in dota 2 scene . New players should check out his guide "Welcome to dota you suck" . My overall rating for dota2 gonna be 9/10 . there are some problem with match making or just my bad luck ? .

review: A standard match of Dota 2 features the strongholds of two opposing factions, the Radiant and the Dire, containing critical structures called "Ancients", which are surrounded by a number of lesser buildings. The bases of these two factions are connected by three main paths, referred to as "lanes", which are guarded by defensive towers, as well as autonomous units called "creeps", which periodically spawn in groups and traverse the lanes, attacking enemy units or structures they encounter. The Dota 2 map is functionally symmetrical, despite having a number of critical differences conferring a variety of advantages and disadvantages to each side. The Radiant is based at the southwest corner of the map, while the Dire is based at the northeast corner; the two sides are divided by a river that runs perpendicular to the central lane. The two teams, typically composed of five players each, are pitted against one another to compete as the defenders for their respective Ancients.[6] Featured across the map are hostile units referred to as "neutrals", which are not aligned to either faction and are primarily located in the forests. Located on the northeast side of the river is a "boss" called "Roshan", who typically requires multiple team members to kill and drops strategically powerful items.

review: This game is AWESOME!
game-hours: 915.8
review: The adventure from the WC3 DOTA 1 to Heroes of Newerth to DOTA 2 was an interesting trek. I stopped playing DOTA 1 around the time Batrider was added, stopped playing HoN when Midas was added, and am still playing DOTA 2 to this day. I recall in DOTA 1 when everyone used wc3banlist with auto refreshing slots and autobanning over 100ms players. People never warded, sentries were hardly used and everyone was pretty bad overall. It was a  load of fun however, particularily because so many people I knew were engrossed in DOTA and played nothing else. (Except CS 1.6) Techies remote mining Roshan, feeding your carries with gold (WC3 share gold feature), Phantom Assassin's evasion made her basically invisible minus her shadow... the list goes on. Heroes of Newerth was a title that I hadn't heard of until my friend mentioned it and I got to use his BETA account, shortly after it was launched for $20. Amazing, all the DOTA heroes and items, but with a few new additions every so often. The graphics were much better than DOTA 1 and everything sounded badass. (Portal Key sound is still engrained in my mind.) The problem was that it eventually went F2P with "freemium" features like paid heroes to compete with League of Legends and the DOTA 2 official "open beta" launch. Now we have DOTA 2. Crisp graphics, Valve supremacy, Gaben. Cosmetic only purchasables, very functional UI, solid framerates on any mid-range gaming PC, Valve supremacy, Gaben. I'm just listing the stuff I like. Mirana, smoothness of heroes turning (Suck it, League), Active Items (Suck it again, League), and Valve supremacy. Gaben. Gabe up writing this review because I'm at work and a bunch of customers are here.

game-hours: 80.6
review: DOTA 2 adds a great deal of complexity to the MOBA genre. Its balance tenet is: "Everything goes." There is no character that is underpowered; in fact, they're all overpowered in their own way. The game places a great burden of knowledge over whoever tries it out. Be sure to stick to Co-op games for starters. The tutorial may prepare you slightly, but the game as a whole is a lot more complex than other MOBAs on the market. Oh, and the saying "It ain't over till it's over" applies here. You can't be sure you're winning until the Radiant/Dire goes down. Lots of rooms for comebacks in here, but the game is far more snowbally than other MOBAs.

review: Short review Pros +Absolutely no pay to win +Really depends on your skills, teamwork (and connection) +huge variety on 1 map (100+ heroes, many items build to combine) +Its fun if you have good team (and own the match) +Many game modes which is fun but some of them requires great experience +Doesn't really need high PC spec, but need good connection but still got good graphich and gameplay +Customizing hero with the store item is fun, the items are cool but some of them can cost like $400 for a piece of item (i will be much fun if you are rich  kid) +you can practice with bot offline +Many more -Can get IMBA (imbalance, your enemies is too strong because of tricks and builds, you have to be clever to counter) -Usually, players from *********** can get annoying (rude behaviour, noisy voice chat, and sometimes they suck (no offense)) -Can really2 cause you slamming your keyboard for many reasons (meaning : stress) -Even if you are really good, 1 trashy teammate / 1 trashy action from your teammate and boom. uninstall this game. -Feeder (someone who dont kill, but killed by enemy a lot/ Stupid noobsh*t) everywhere -The community isn't bad, but not the best at all (trash talkers, trade scammers) -I'll tell you one more time, if you are not the patient type at all, i suggest avoid this game. -Low prior system (leaving an active game penalty for more than 5 minutes which is called abandon) sometimes is annoying Conclusion: A really2 fun game, Literally its only 1 map but its just never makes me boring (except there's a feeder) But sometimes it's really annoying because...... human make mistakes Its really a fair game but can be really unfair 1 player can lose or win the game its all about balance... review: When I hear the phrase "Dota 2 is good, just look at how many people play it," I can't help but make myself blue from facepalming so hard. Call of Duty has millions of players. The thing is they're all 12 year olds with tourrettes and particularly ignorant mothers. The gaming society is so fanatic about numbers that they forget that criticism and praise are reflections of an individual's formed beliefs. That being said, Dota 2 is a terrible game, and that's not an opinion; it's the truth. Valve's fear of the number 3 has thrown them afar by pushing number 2's (yes, I did just say that, laugh it up) of all their other series. Portal 2, Left 4 Dead 2 and Half Life 2 as well as Half Life 2: Episode 2. But now they are doing it to games they don't originally own! Repetition is useful in debates and extremely rarely in games. A lesson Valve is eagerly forgetting to the point where Dota 2 doesn't even have multiple maps to change things up. I see it's up to the players to pose new situations; how inadvertently lethargic. I cannot comprehend how players can have over 3000 hours doing the same thing; let alone 5. To put this in today's terms; Dota 2 is so stupid your mum asked me what I was doing and when I replied "I'm playing Defense of the Ancients" she freaked out believing that I was attempting to prevent her murder. I weep for future generations that, when asked to list 10 goods things about the 21st century, can only find numerous references to swag, Justin Bieber and the mindset that a large amount of players in a game means everyone in the whole world should enjoy it. And before you ask, yes I did just put a 'your mum is so old' joke in an analysis, thanks for noticing.

review: This game is awesome
game-hours: 2303.3
review: This game.............. Is why I'm Dota_heaD. From the depths of 2002's Warcraft III: Reign of Chaos and later 2003's The Frozen Throne expansion released two different versions of Defense Of The Ancients in Use Map Settings custom game mode. The game was a wild success. The Frozen Throne version is the truest to Dota 2's gameplay, items, heroes, and spells. RoC DotA was arguably more fun for hardcore players but TFT soared in popularity. This remake, unlike HoN (which is honestly the better game in several aspects), takes all the old skills, revamps them, gives them new Aghanim's Scepter buffs, and makes warding a nightmare (seriously though, warding in HoN is a pleasure compared to Dota 2). Dota 2 is my most-played go-to game. It elicits the greatest feelings of disappointment and triumph alike! The community in Dota 2 is abysmal but that includes ME! The untrollable troll! So if you're well prepared for pointless criticisms of item-builds, know-it-all noobs who've played under 500 games and presume to think they've already seen everything this game has to offer.... you're in luck! Honestly though, this game is like a religion. If you're not deeply invested into it, you'll never be particularly good and you'll NEVER enjoy the game, not even once. This game commands your attention like no other. This game challenges your patience for other human beings like no other. This game will drive you insane. And you will thank yourself for it.

review: It's an amazing game - technically outstanding, showing all of Valve's usual polish and attention to detail, especially in the all-important multiplayer aspects. The continual balance tweaks and new heroes combined with the vast amount of content in the game offer countless hours of enjoyment. It's hard to master but good wins with your teammates are incredibly satisfying. It took me a long time to warm up to, but I'm helplessly addicted and every day look forward to getting home to fire this up with my friends. If you can spare the time - play it.

game-hours: 4.8
review: I think people who gush over this game do so because it's not League of Legends. This often strikes me as being the same as the person who plays say The Secret World and bashes those that play World of Warcraft. Where World of Warcraft is accessible, easy and enjoyable for the masses, Secret world is deep, complex and very rewarding to those who really enjoy the minutae of figuring out how to get the most out of an MMO. DOTA 2 is the game you play when you don't want to the hand-holding, comfortable ease that League of Legends has brought to the MOBA world. I found DOTA 2 to be overly awkward, and not particularly rewarding. But for those in the mood for the more "hardcore" experience, this is where to be, I just won't be there with you.

game-hours: 1069.1
review: Possibly one of the most interesting games in my Steam Library, Dota 2 is an enjoyable game to play with friends online and meet new people in the online matches. After the recent success of the Internations 2014 by raising a whopping prize pool of over ten million dollars. This serves as an incentive for new players at the possibility to winning a share of the prize pool if they're good at the game. One will require the ability to quickly respond to the situation as the actions of your teammates and enemies are completely random. I suggest this game to anyone who wants an enjoyable experience thats more complicated than the similar game League of Legends. I find both games equally fun and enjoyable however Dota is ultimately the more superior game between the two. ~SamuraiZheng

game-hours: 1926.5
review: DotA 2 is a very unique game in terms of the meta game and community. There are multiple features that distinguish it between other MOBA's, and because of that uniqueness you are very dependant on your team. DotA has a very interesting Meta game as there are hero patches every few months which could change the entire game, but it could also ruin the whole game. In DotA you can select one of 100+ heroes and all for free (No microtransactions required to boost In game performance, purely aesthetics) which is also pretty challenging when you first start off, but once you play for awhile then you will get used to it. The ingame gameplay can be changed depending on yourself as you can decide whether or not you want to build your hero differently, troll, or complain the entire game. The community is very toxic and WILL judge you, you will encounter foreigner's who "invade" your servers and they will speak in their primary language which you will most likely not speak their language (If you are annoyed then there is a mute feature within the game). Out of experience in most MOBA's + RTS, I would highly recommend this game to you but you must put time and effort for it to become fun. Hope you have fun! Tl;Dr ~ DotA2 is not P2W, It has it's unique features, Many free heroes to play with, Toxic community, Takes long to learn the game

game-hours: 1265.7
review: It's an amazing game - technically outstanding, showing all of Valve's usual polish and attention to detail, especially in the all-important multiplayer aspects. The continual balance tweaks and new heroes combined with the vast amount of content in the game offer countless hours of enjoyment. It's hard to master but good wins with your teammates are incredibly satisfying. It took me a long time to warm up to, but I'm helplessly addicted and every day look forward to getting home to fire this up with my friends. If you can spare the time - play it.

game-hours: 1296.4
review: PROOOSSS
game-hours: 1805.2
review: best game ever
game-hours: 288.8
review: This game is without a doubt the freest free to game out there. Everything is free right off the bat and that makes a huge difference in gameplay. There are no buffs that you can buy before the game that would have even the slightest impact on the match. The only thing you pay for is cosmetic items, which again, have no effect on gameplay. Heroes are fun to play and range in difficutly, so other charcters take more time and paicientce to master. There is also a wide range of charcters types to play as so you never get bored. From the ranged characters, to the melee characters, to the nukers, to the tanks there will always be a fun and interesting character that fits your playstyle. Though Dota 2 plays out similar to other MOBA's, it is very diverse in its playstyles. Do not treat it like games like League of Ledgends. It's a completly different game entireley and should be treated as such. That being said the learning curve is very difficult, and other players on Dota are extremely unforgiving. Your first few games will be rough, but after one good game or your first win it's hard to step away from the computer. And once you learned your prefered playstyle and find a character you enjoy, Dota 2 can be one of the most addicting games you've ever played. Dota 2 is one of the best games in the MOBA genre and for good reason. Gameplay is fun and challenging, and there is a hero for everybody. Though it will take awhile for you to start getting the hang of things, the rewards are well worth the time and effort.

review: Alright so unlike most people who don't recommend Dota 2, I just legitametely did not like the game, though I understand how others would. Dota 2 has similar gameplay to Planescape Torment, A game which i played for story aspects. I couldn't even get through the tutorial without feeling bored and unprogressive. Now I don't play many multiplayer games but from my experience the gameplay of Dota 2 does not match its purpose, So if your like me, who enjoys games where you can see clear progression, you enjoy becoming stronger and stronger and are a fan of the WASD keys, I do not suggest it. 3.5/10

game-hours: 3407.8
review: The game is fun. There is no doubt about that. It is fun and frustrating at the same time. You have to work as a team. You and you alone aren't going to decide the outcome of a match. Unfortunately, it seems to have most of the same trappings as Valve's other F2P game, Team Fortress 2. The items introduced into the game have little to no quality control. Thankfully, we have yet to see items that affect the stats of the characters themselves. Dota 2 is one of the best MOBAs in the genre, but far from the most popular. Dota 2 allows you to play all of the heroes that the game offers without spending antyhing, but similar games only allow you to play a small, rotation free hero pool. You must then purchase the each hero individuall with in-game currency or real money. Dota 2 is far better in this sense. Dota 2 also seems to be a bit more high-level than other games in the same genre. This can be both good and bad as it allows for you to reach a higher skill ceiling, but it can be discouraging to new players. The community can be vile and the punishments for "leaving" a game are strict. If you have connection problems or have other commitments that won't allow you to spend updwards of an hour at the computer, I don't think that this is something you could enjoy. Since it is free, I'd recommend you pick it up and give it a try. I will update this review to be more in-depth at a later time.

game-hours: 1049.5
review: Each match of Dota 2 is independent and involves two teams, both containing five players and each occupying a stronghold at either end of the map. Located in each stronghold is a building called the "Ancient"; to win, a team must destroy the enemy's Ancient. Each player controls a "Hero" character and focuses on leveling up, collecting gold, acquiring items and fighting against the other team to achieve victory. Overall, this game is a very intense and full of war occurrences, spell caster, magic and physical damage, even the absolutely stunning built-up for every each heroes. This game, Dota 2, is the best multi-player game available on the market yet...!

review: It's a pretty fun game if you hate yourself
game-hours: 1925.4
review: just one more game.... I know this is the 5th time I said it! I don't really believe it anyway either! This is easily one of the best Free-to-Play games. It is NOT free-to-win or anything like that. Nothing you buy has ANY effect on the gameplay. You are essentially paying just to play dress-up with your characters (and you get those items for free through playing anyway!) It is a HUGE game, and you WILL SUCK HORRIBLY at first. Choose a fairly simple hero (probably a support first) and learn how they work before you switch heroes. WATCH THE PROS! There are some free games and tournaments to watch and learn how the game is played and they are actually FUN TO WATCH. The community is probably 40-60 between welcoming players and A$$holes. Make friends with the good ones and keep playing with them, or better yet play with some of your REAL friends and suck horribly together! After about 300-1000 hours of playing, you might only suck a bit, though you'll probably still suck pretty bad. By that point there's no turning back -- you will be a DOTA2 player for life! and it will be GLORIOUS! The only people I would NOT reccommend this to are: people with limited time (games average 25-45 mins and can go past an hour) people who get frustrated easily or let the griefers get to them (thin skin will do you in!) people who can't communicate or like to do things their own way -- this is THE TEAM GAME. Listen to your team to win, or listen to your team  you out.

review: Dota 2 at first doesn't seem like one of the best games but once you get into it and get some hours on the clock playing, you'll notice how you can endlessly enjoy the game. The bonus to that is that there are no cheaters and people that might ruin the game for you. The game mechanics are designed well although some heroes/champions are over powerered if you master them over other ones. The in-game purchases have nothing to do with player performance, you can buy skins or rather 'clothes' for them making you stand out but don't improve your skills or anything. Overall I rate the game 8/10. -1 for some heroes over powered. -1 for the dota 2 network being a problem.

review: ^^
game-hours: 1025.5
review: Dota 2 is one of the most fantastic strategy game i've ever played. There are some few things i'd like to review about some great features that Dota 1 hasnt: 1) Customize In-Game Effects. Valve really did a great job by adding some feature like customize hero with different types of armor. You can also customize courier, announcer, mega-kill voice, and loading screen. Good news is those items can be earned from drops after game that have a different drop chance depend on its rarity, the higher rarity = the better looks of items. so more play = more items ! :) 2) Level-system. Just like every online game does, you can't refuse a level-system. In Dota 2, The higher the level means the higher rarity of items you can get. You can earn a higher level by gaining battle points from every game you play 3) Ranked Match Feature. Valve also added ranked match feature. I think this is the very reason why i move to Dota 2 from Dota 1. After you reach level 13, you'll be able to play ranked match. There are two kinds of ranked match, first solo ranked match, second party ranked match. Solo ranked match works if you play alone (without party), party ranked match works if you play with your party that consist of 2,3 or 5 people. More rating you get means more skilled-person you can play with. 4) Watch Live Game and In-Game Replay Download. In Dota 1, you have to be an observer to watch a game. In Dota 2, Valve makes it easier by adding "Watch" tab in game. From this feature, you can spectate every single game from Steam server, not to mention you can also watch a professional match that is available everyday. If you think the game you watched is interesting, you are able to download the replay everytime and learn from it. I'm sorry for bad english, I hope this review's helpful. Regards, Heisenberg.
