game-hours: 424.0
review: DotA 2 popped my MOBA cherry, and what an experience its been. At first I was skeptical, there is only one map, one objective for every game. But the vast array of heros, items and builds open up a world of possibility, add this to the four other team members you have to be able to work effectively with and it can give hours (338 and counting) of enjoyment, frustration and everything in between as you work towards knocking down the enemy ancient and the hope for reward. For the chance of better team play, try ranked. The games will be harder, but the reward of a higher MMR makes people more willing to work together (or innundate your chat box with colourful slurs).

review: Dota 2 is awesome. I highly recommend playing this game with friends, it's a lot funnier that way. You will learn to be a part of a team. It can be really good when you are stressed out, as it can easily distract you. There are also some bad things about it. For example, people rage and flame too much. The worst thing that can happen to you in Dota is when all players in the game are flaming you. You will be come angrier when playing this game. Don't get me wrong, there are people who play Dota and don't flame or rage. Finding these people can be hard, therefore I suggest playing with friends. Dota can make you happy, you can have a good laugh while playing it. Remember, if you are already angry and raging too much in the game, go make a pause and come back later.

game-hours: 489.2
review: This is a great game. Basically, the game has great graphics, in my opinion (many beg to differ though.). Great gameplay with all the minor mechanics like every character having different casting time (depending on animation), turning time of heroes, and all those little things that will go a very long way to give depth to this game. Below I will state the "YAYS" & "NAYS" of this game: YAYS: 1. Great gameplay with all the little mechanics (turning times, skill casting delays due to animation, voice overs [which usually is easily taken for granted], etc) 2. Nice work of the revamp of all characters(includes creeps, all shops) 3. Report player feature (Great for s who like to cyber bully and make this game an unenjoyable one) 4. Player States 5. Great variety of customisation with most characters (at a price, of course.) NAYS: 1. BOTS' AI require more work on it especially on the engaging part. They either stone there after you've pinged them countless of times to engage, or they do a follow up after you get caught by surprise and "intentionally feed" given the situation of 1 v 4. 2. Lack of other heroes and the release of heroes are taking a really long long time. 3. The BOTS in your team mostly aim their skills in the wrong direction. CONCLUSION: Despite it's short comings, like all games, they could always use some improvements. All in all, this is a very enjoyable game to play, and I hope that improvements and endless content will continue to grow because new content is always refreshing, and in my opinion, it's something that keeps players wanting more. NOTE: This review is subjective different end users. Some may agree with it, some may not. At the end of the day, please show tolerance, and restraint even if you disagree with what people have to say.

game-hours: 16.4
review: I am going to face the consequences of not agreeing with thousands of satisfied gamers, but unfortunately I really can't say I would recommend Dota to anyone. When I was playing the Warcraft 3 mod I was so excited to know that someone was planning to create a whole new game with it (alot of years, accounts, pcs ago...) that I started playing it as soon as it was possible. After some years here I am again, and unfortunately I have to say that I am very disappointed with this game. We know of the awful community, we know of the slow paced mechanics (which may even be a perk for someone), but we can't really accept in this era, an outdated graphic, a really unfriendly interface, and the feeling of general polish lackness that we would expect from a game of this height. Talking from my graphic knowledge, the purity of a well rendered game is to be shown when all the FFXAA postprocessing is off. We clear the bloom, we clear the lightnings, we clear fogs, shinings, reflections, and the core grafic of this game is (in comparison of doing the same with other similar games) so outdated that a tear of nostalgy dropped from my eye, as I was sure I was playing Warcraft. But it's not Warcraft in the far 2002, it's 2015, and we can't really accept such poligonal scarsity and approximative physics. And if you think that I am just asking too much, well, the fact would not be a trouble for me, if it would not give the game an awful, outdated look: not vintage, not nostalgic, just... old. A word should be spent for the well known trouble of the toxic community. If some kind of community, broadly talking, is harassed and worsened by a group of troublemakers, it's imperative that the leaders of the said community do something to resolve the problem ...but no real solutions are being taken. Bans, low priority queues, and such easy going methods probably just worsened the issue, giving the toxic part of the community not a direct message. This could translate as following: if the toxicity of a part of the community is such alarming, and you should care about this trouble, and you can't, well or you are unable to fix it, or you in the end are happy with this (which option I don't know is the worse). Taken singularly Dota 2 is a real game experience that every gamer should do, maybe just for some hours, but putting Dota2 in relation with its most famous counterparts (League of Legends and Heroes of the Storm, to say two names), I am sad to say that my favourite moba looks like the unlucky little brother. Unfortunately this issues can't be closed by a "it's just a matter of tastes" statement: to play this game, and to be happy playing it, we need to fix some technical facts, which the most important are the followings: - a total graphic update, from maps, to buildings, to clutters to (PLEASE) champions; - new physics (never heard of motion capture?), because for freak sake champions move like monsters in Warcraft 3; - a decent interface, both in and off game; - a capital solution for the (broadening) toxicity of the community, because if I wanted to play just with bots in some sort of solo, I'd play GTA, Skyrim, or Dungeon Keeper (always wonderful). To be brutally honest, playing Dota is like finally going out for a drink with your crush, but the beer is awful, there is a terrible karaoke playing at like 3 yards from your table, the food is rancid and the waitress kicks you in the balls because you look like her cheating ex boyfriend. Could be a wonderful experience, but too many things go wrong, and they ruin it. 6,5/10: play it, but there is much better around nowadays.

game-hours: 1699.1
review: Well where do I start with this game well Dota 2 involves a lot of communication you can't just run in and expect a kill when the enemy team is all around you . Learning your role will really help your team you can't win a game with 5 hard carrots and no one to support you . Now to get to the Russian part it's hard to play dota when your in a team and every one speaks different language one way to get pass that is use you communication wheel getting mad at them for not understanding you and you not understanding them is no reason for you to hate Russians . Yes I understand that you pick US east or west and there are people from Russia or ukrain on that same server you are on . Anyway if this is the first type of Moba I suggest you take your time to look at the settings and learn your controls before you just jump in to the 5v5 and make your team mad for feeding or not learning your role . It takes time to get use to the game just by the controls also you need to learn roles ,counters , and ganking . Dota 2 was my first Moba over all it's one of the best Moba's out there very challenging and fun if you learn and have friends to play with .

game-hours: 3356.2
review: Dota 2 is really complex strategy game. There are always a counter for your hero and strategy; and some heroes also has a steep learning curves. But this kind of complexity is what I enjoy the most because winning and having a good match would be rewarding. No pay-to-win (except for some special event matches, which you can ignore if you want), and basically it really depends on your skills and knowledge to win the game. Beyond the gaming aspect, I really love how Dota 2 supports the development of e-Sports industry. I think in digital era like now, gaming should not be regarded only for time-killer but also a money-earning way. I really love how Dota develop their Watch-in-game tournaments and live match, commentator and spectators system, and so on. The gaming community also amazing in terms of developing Dota 2 as an gaming industry. The only downside for Dota 2 is the awful and harsh player community in most games recently. I found a lot of respectful and friendly players during the early access (beta) stage. But after it officially released, a lot of new players coming and sadly more people do the trash-talk in game. Not all the guys are bad thou. If you are new, go find some nice and pro pub player in twitch and learn from them; be patience and learn small numbers of heroes first.

review: Positive dota 2 things: - graphic Negative dota 2 things: - no regionlock - game offers you possibility to "choose server and leanguage" but this is a lie. Every one serv, no metter do it is US, EU, or any other is full of RUSSIANS speaking only in RUSSIAN leanguage. Game is unplayable for solo players, who are always matchmaked with russians, peruvians, or others who dont use english even if they pick so. - forced elo hell - Dota 2 have worst ranking system in MOBA's world. All newbies dont start at 0 mmr or something but they get very high MMR at the beginning - what does this mean? That mean that even if You are playing 3 years in dota You will be forced to play with total newbies in RANKED GAMES. I know, hard to belive, but this is how it goes here. - epic fail report system - You can report anyone for anything, and nobody check this. There was many times, when people who had chat muted has beeen reported for insults, etc, and they was punished by system and goes to low prio pool. 9/10 matches you will be playing in full russian team in solo queue and 5/10 times they will report You because You are not russian. Dota 2 make this real. - Scamm - Dota 2 is full of scammers, sharks, etc, and DOTA 2 GIVE NO SUPPORT FOR VICTIMS OF SHARKING OR SCAMM. DOTA2LOUNGE IS BIGGEST SCAMM WEBSIDE AND COOPERATE WITH VALVE COMPANY ALL THE TIME. SICK BUT REAL. - unstable servers - every single event story goes round. A lot of crashes, disconnections, and bugs. Worst thing is that if game disconnect You because of unstable Valve servers You gonna get LEAVER status and you are out of normal playing (low prio). - sick community market. If You will buy something in dota 2 shop for about (for example) 2,99 euro, next day Your items gonna be sold for 0,05-0,1 eu at community market. There is no reason to buy anything in this game, but even when You will buy something You gonna regret that soon. - steam forums. Official place for dota 2 community are steam forums. This is worst place in web, leaded by VOLOUNTEER MODERATORS. They simpple shut down every topic against dota sick rules, and every trolled topic. For example: You will create topic: "Newbie looking for team", and after 2 days there gonna be offtop answer in Your topic. VOLOUNTEER MODERATORS will not warn, or punish offtopers, oh no. They will CLOSE YOUR TOPIC, because someone else will troll Your thread. Next sick thing about this "place" - 0 support - I was supporting this game for about 3 years (from closed beta). I bought many items, packs and boosts , but when once i was unhappy, because at the time of diretide bugs wasted my 2,29 eu boost VALVE COMPANY DIDNT WANTED TO REFUND BOOST. In the fact support didnt answered at all on my ticket. Next time when my account was hijacked and someone stolen courier from my inventory steam support didnt helped me too. At the present day i am fighting for a refund for item bought for event. Overall: Valve Company is worst of all for me, they have 0 honour, and have 0 respect for players in mine opinion after 3 years of supporting them. If You need any help support simple ignoring You. So generally if You want to have fun You will not find any fun in this game. This game was created by other company, and they did very great job. Now game is in the hand of Valve company and this is it biggest failure. Valve company is in the fact very bad company, they dont listen players, they dont do what players want, they all the time experimenting using us, and our money. Game is very laggy and crashable, but You will never get any compensate for wasted boosts or something of a kind, if this was Valve fault. I am saying again - this company is crap, who have 0 honour and 0 respect for players. You gonna play 2 years trying to get to higher MMR pool, but You will only TRY. game-hours: 196.7
review: Theres an adage that the Dota 2 community often quotes when someone identifies themselves as a new player. Welcome to Dota 2! They say, with open arms, before concluding with, You suck. They're not wrong: for the first dozen hours or so, you'll be bombarded with too much information and an often unforgiving community of extremely competitive players. But if you persevere, Dota 2 becomes one of the most rewarding and tense team-based multiplayer experiences anywhere in gaming. It's an achievement owed to uncompromising depth, a ridiculously generous free-to-play model, and the great features developer Valve has built up around it. Valve's artists deserve praise for a crisp and readable style that, after some practice, makes it possible to tell what's going on even in a massive brawl where both teams of five colorful fantasy characters collide and cast spells at once. However, credit for the intimidatingly complex design of Dota 2 belongs to the original Defense of the Ancients mod (known as DOTA) for Warcraft III, which kicked off the MOBA genre. Valve (after hiring on DOTA's key developers) has copied that formula almost to the letter, and as a result Dota 2 has become notorious even among its MOBA peers for its difficulty  and thats totally justified. Its a double-edged sword that leads to both a terrifying introduction and a world-class competitive game at the highest levels. As such, you should not expect to have fun your first day playing... or even your first week. That sounds like a cardinal sin of gaming, but theres method to this madness. In short, Dota 2 is a deeply layered construct of systems, and to survive you need to understand every single one and how they interact with one another. Everything from learning to work as a member of a coordinated team to the counter-intuitive practice of killing your own AI units to deny the enemy experience points and gold theyd get from doing it themselves, and understanding the effects of hundreds of complex abilities like Bloodseekers Rupture (which deals huge damage with every step you take) is a big barrier to entry. Even figuring out which of the 102 heroes (and counting) fits you best is a time-consuming challenge. Initially, youre thrown into the deep end to flounder, trying out any hero that makes the slightest bit of sense. The selection is bewildering: playing as Riki with his permanent invisibility from level 6 on is an obvious choice, as it's hard to kill what you can't see. Drow Ranger, perhaps, with her obscene damage the instant she unlocks her "ultimate" ability at level 6, and her slowing Ice Arrows that enable both escapes and setting up a kill. On the more complex end of the spectrum you have choices like the armour-manipulating Templar Assassin, or the incredibly mobile Storm Spirit, who can dart around the battlefield and avoid damage by simply not being in the wrong place at the wrong time. On top of that there are well over 100 items to choose from within each game, each with their own ways of manipulating and enhancing your stats and suite of active abilities. Your learning has just begun when you've settled on what roles, heroes, and builds suit you best  you also have to adapt based on what other players choose. If the other team plays a Riki, you need to compensate with an emphasis on detection. Go up against Bloodseeker and his hideously powerful Rupture will force you to carry around a Town Portal Scroll to get home in a hurry. To grasp the subtleties of how heroes interact and fight you have to do more homework on the different kinds of damage and how theyre mitigated; how to prevent one type of spell from affecting you, and when you use that countermeasure; how the different kinds of aggro work, and when you need to manipulate them; the timers (which aren't made visible), and how to optimise your play around them. Even after all that, to avoid being caught at a disadvantage you must be taught the nuanced techniques that can make or break games, which Dota 2 seems to almost belligerently hide from new players. Tricks like pulling a group of neutral monsters out of their home so that a new group can spawn to effectively double the rewards are never hinted at. This forced me to read and educate my outside of Dota 2, which had the positive effect of introducing me to the player community and making me feel like a part of it. It's almost like an oral tradition that binds together a tribe. This is a balancing system that could only exist in a game where everybody has access to all heroes, and Valve wisely obliges. All of Dota 2, including its growing cast of 102 characters, is available from the moment you complete the all-too-brief tutorial. And that delicate system can only survive if the items for sale have zero effect on gameplay. Again, Valve has come through. Only cosmetic enhancements, almost all of which are created by the community and held to a very high standard, and tournament goodies (such as tickets for viewing live events) are for sale. Theres not a single paid advantage that could have the slightest impact on the in-game balance, and thats an amazing situation unrivalled among Dota 2s closest competition. Pretty much everything I've praised Dota 2 for, outside of being totally free, is taken directly from the outstanding original mod. Where Valve has taken initiative to make Dota 2 a significantly better experience is in everything surrounding it, including improving the pre-game matchmaking interface, supporting the community of professional and avid players, and even allowing artists to create and sell cosmetic items on the Dota 2 store. Perhaps most important are the steps Valve has taken toward taming the hyper-competitive community. Besides matchmaking, guilds, and a wide variety of different game modes, the things that Valve hasnt done are just as noticeable than the things it has. For example, theres no concede button to throw in the towel on a losing match, and though you earn a matchmaking rank to ensure you're placed competitively, it's not visible to other players. If withholding those features seems like a bad idea on the surface, their sacrifice was not in vain  it prevents irritable players from dropping out of a match at the first sign of defeat, or when they're teamed up with people whose stats don't meet their exacting standards  a real frustration in other MOBAs. LIkewise, Valve recognized that less is more when it comes to unlockables. Theres no progression outside of the game that will have the slightest mechanical effect inside of it. Without artificial goals to aim for, the matches are left with a strong and refreshing sense of fairness and purity, where everything that can influence success or failure is right there on the battlefield and in your head. In my personal experience, Valves ideas work. I've played for over 1,000 hours, and my encounters with people unwilling to act decently towards their fellow players have become increasingly rare over the course of Dota 2s development. It has never been more friendly than it is now  though thats a relative comparison. Even with these enhancements, the best way to play Dota 2 will always be with a team of four friends. Valves dogged desire to preserve DOTA's design perfectly is a double-edged sword in some ways. There are a few design choices that feel needlessly archaic and slavish to the original, such as the way Blink Dagger will arbitrarily shave 200 units of movement from your blink if you overestimate the distance, or how the towers will occasionally refuse to acknowledge your attempts to turn aggro away from yourself during a siege. They feel like relics of previous era, traditions carried on for the sake of tradition.

game-hours: 1532.2
review: You go to see Bill Murray -- not the movie he's in. No matter how mediocre the film, time spent with him is always rewarding. That absurdist deadpan has served him since the Carter-era "Saturday Night Live." And in his latest, "Groundhog Day," the shtick is still funny. For a time, the movie's pretty good too. "Groundhog" will never be designated a national film treasure by the Library of Congress. But, in terms of vehicle selection, this is one of the better ones Murray has hitched himself to. In fact, its "Twilight Zone"-type premise (scripted by Danny Rubin and director Harold Ramis) is initially intriguing. A people-hating weatherman on a Pittsburgh TV station, Murray's waiting for his real ship to come in. "For your information, Hairdo," he asserts to a well-coiffed colleague at WPBH, "there's a news channel interested in me." Until that questionable possibility, however, he must content himself with such hated aspects of his job as the annual trip on Groundhog Day. For this inane (to his mind) festival, he must join the reporting flocks at Punxsutawney, Pa., to catch the yearly appearance of the spring-determining rodent. If the divining "Punxsutawney Phil" sees his furry shadow, six more weeks of winter are due. If he doesn't, the thaw is on. Now back for his fourth Groundhog Day, Murray -- with producer Andie MacDowell and cameraman Chris Elliott -- waits impatiently for the day to end. But this time, it doesn't. After a full day's work at the festival, Murray wakes up to exactly the same morning -- Groundhog Day II. The clock radio plays "I Got You Babe" like it did the morning before. An impending blizzard is announced once more. Stephen Tobolowsky, a horrifying nerd from Murray's high-school past now in insurance, recognizes him -- again. Even MacDowell and Elliott are gearing up to film the festival as if for the first time. Murray realizes he's stuck in time. No matter what he does, the next day is the same day. Only he remembers. This allows him to anticipate trouble. "Ned, I would love to stand here and talk with you," he tells Tobolowsky at their umpteenth chance meeting. "But I'm not going to." The time/space dilemma presents a variety of options, from fun to purgatorial. Murray is immortal, in effect. He can survive death games. He can teach himself piano. He can find out basic information from attractive local Marita Geraghty, for instance, then wow her the next time around with apparent inside knowledge. But he becomes increasingly interested in MacDowell and spends most of the time working on her. But he only has a day to impress her; it's back to square one at 6 the next morning. The trouble is, you'll feel like you've been through too many same days yourself. With its zany daily episodes, "Groundhog" gets stuck in a non-progressive repetition. It's also headed for the usual Hollywood Life Lesson, in which Murray's moral winter must thaw. But even through the most creatively frigid sections, Murray is amusing as he reacts to the longest day of his life. He gets to work on that recurring Tobolowsky meeting, for one thing. The best way to send the insurance agent screaming into the distance, Murray finds, is to embrace him for a suggestively long moment, caress his back and say: "I don't know where you're needed, but couldn't you call in sick?"

game-hours: 3.5
review: I don't get it why this game is so popular. Most probably one has to be very, very simple minded to find this thingie entertaining. This game is extremely boring, as well as super repetitive - and I did not play it for more than 20 minutes online, plus the tutorials to get to this conclusion (first tutorial mission was fun as a first impression, but the next was the same thing with same monsters, etc, but a different "hero", then the same thing came again... and again... and again...). Dota 2 is like Torchlight or Diablo (point, click, point, click, point, click until your nose starts running), except it's even more simpler related to action (there's no world or story or anything in Dota as it's "MOBA"), on the other hand, for a starter there's a confusingly long list of characters and items, which are never explained, but later turns out they don't give much to complexity. There are also wide range and wild pricing in-game purchases, which makes me understand how the huge prize pools are built for tournaments of this game. So, to sum it up, if you are not a smart person, easily entertained, and most importantly, repetitive tasks with minor changes (misleading you to think you are "progressing" and "going somewhere") make you addicted, as well as you want to spend crazy money on virtual stuff, Dota 2 is your game (or WoW, or WOT, or whatever, anything built around the same concept of sucking in people, turning them into junkies and destroying their lives). You can hate me for seeing it like that. You can down-vote too. But right after your rage is gone, please stop for a moment and think about what I wrote above. Then do a favor to yourself: do not use your computer for one week (at least, no video games at all - nothing! Not even minesweeper!). On day 8, you'll find out you was a junkie and did not have fun at all playing a game, but was grinding for your next dose. Thanks for reading.

game-hours: 1145.8
review: PASTILAN
game-hours: 261.2
review: While many Action RTS games tried to take its place, the original DOTA mod was still played for a long time until this semi-remake, semi-port. It retains everything that made the original great, with an improved engine and metasystem. Built-in matchmaking makes things balanced between players, great workshop support for cosmetics, and the best F2P system around make it an overall more enjoyable experience to the original. However, due to the port trying to be 1:1 with the original, some features that could've been changed remain the same. There are a few concepts that, while making sense over time, are baffling to new players, and it's that complexity that is DOTA's greatest strength, as well as its major weakness. It's very hard for new players to hop in and enjoy, especially compared to other Action RTS games that find a better balance between depth and accessability to new players. Despite this, after putting in time DOTA is one of the most rewarding and unique experiences in gaming, one that has yet to be matched.

game-hours: 702.4
review: It is really hard to write a review about a game that I love yet brings such rage and anger to me. Obviously this is the same concept as LoL and it has the same gameplay formula. It has it's positives and it's negatives. I have found that a few positives are that the characters are varied and somewhat interesting and their backstories always seem like a good read, it also does not force you to pay for characters to play them such as LoL or Smite, there are no items that the community can buy for their characters that offer bonuses when bought outside the game. They are purely cosmetic, so if you want your character to look nicer then that is there for you. Now I hate to write negatives about games that I actually enjoy but this is a personal peeve of mine. I want to play with people in East or West Europe? That's fine I don't mind meeeting them. However when I get Russians on those servers instead of their own and calling me every name in the book and giving me hell then I begin to get a little mad. Another thing that really grinds me is when the servers can connect you into the game and you can go for a good ten or twenty or even 30 minutes playing with no problem and then get a disconnect from server. That brings my blood to a boil and I find this happening a hell of a lot more every day and I get that it is the Year of the Beast Brawl and that is going to be heavily populated, but why the hell should that affect mine and other Dota player's experience? I am going to say that it needs to be fixed or I am just going to have to stop playing this game and I would hate to do that.

game-hours: 1381.4
review: Having over 800+ hours on this game, I can say this game is highly enjoyable with friends! Besides, it is a FREE TO PLAY MOBA. What more could you want? Dota 2 is a heavily based strategy and action multiplayer moba, the idea of the game is to pick 5 heros on both teams (Radiant & Dire) from a pool of over 90+ heros! Both teams take the fight in a beautifully polished landscape, to take down the opposing teams towers and finally taking out the Ancient, whilst gathering gold to purchase items to become more powerful. From my experiance of this game, I would recommend playing with friends. Each game you will play there is no doubt you will come across people from all over the world, within your team there will either be a good communication between you and the team, leading to good team work and you winning the game. However, on the other hand you will have a team that does not have good team work and you will therefore lose the game. That is why I recommend you playing with those who you are able to communicate well with, and those who can work well as a team. Each character within the game are based on different attributes; Strength, Agility & Intelligence. Many people will say that there are a few characters that really over powered, when in fact they are really not. In my opinion this is what makes Dota 2 fun, almost every character can turn the game around. Rikki would have been a good example but now that I think of it, if you had him on your team, you were bound to win. After the recent update I'm not too sure anymore. Anyway you get the idea, there is no pay to win system, cosmetics (that have no effects on the hero) are the only things you can purchase in Dota 2. Fianlly just to top it off, I've never played Dota 1 or anyother moba that is like Dota 2. This currently is my 1st year playing Dota 2 and I can easily say it was the most fun I have ever had, I highly recommend it and yes you will rage and throw your PC outside the window, you will get fed up and you will be glad time to time, but that is Dota 2 for you. If you wish to make sure to check out other reviews!

game-hours: 370.1
review: Defense of the Ancients 2 is a fascinating game. Building upon the success of the MOBA genre, DOTA 2 brings hardcore pvp, strategy, and tactical team based execution of ideas to fruition. The game itself is amazingly beautiful, and simple in initial appearance - Most hero units have 4-6 key skills. However it is a combination of the vast number of heros with their unique abilities and counters in combination with a huge array of items which produce additional effects that makes the tactical possibilities in DOTA 2 simply mind numbing. From soloing a creep lane for gold and xp, to ganking other players with an orchestrated team effort, this game delievers the goods. The only negative I can think of is the player community itself, which can be quite harsh to those still learning the finer points of the game. That point aside, it can be a thrilling and rewarding experience, especially when shared playing with friends, and overcoming skilled opponents. 9/10

game-hours: 1789.6
review: Having played 1.400 hours of Dota 2 so far you can imagine I'm a big fan of the game and I love it, so I'm going to talk about the bad things Dota has instead of the good things.... Firstable Dota 2 is EXTREMELY hard to learn and play properly, this is a proble because many players could just leave this game after a couple of matches. Yes, there are some "Noob-friendly" heroes but I believe that learning and using properly a hero in Dota is the least difficult part of the game. Second bad thing about Dota 2 is MMR; I'm not saying that MMR(Ranked Matchmaking) is broken, doesnt work or things like those, I'm talking mostly about MMR calibration matches. I've played with some players that are actully able to play really well bur are still stuck in "MMR hell" with avg MMR of 1.5 k MMR. When you are there you are in the worst place you can be in Dota 2 because of the absurd amount of flamers, trolls and trash-talkers. Well, these are what I think to be the worst problems of this game; but I still strongly suggest to play this game because it's extremely funny and beautiful. REMEMBER: the community isn't just made of s, there is a bright side. I hope this was interesting :)

game-hours: 1044.6
review: Get ready to get addicted.
game-hours: 961.6
review: goood
game-hours: 1282.7
review: Dota 2 is the first MOBA game I've ever played, and it is AMAZING. I have a lot of games that I like to play, but Dota 2 tops the charts. It is an easy to learn hard to master type of game. Just the type I like. Most FTP games I know have ingame purchases that are practically crucial to progress through the game. That's not the case here. Dota 2 has ingame purchases but they're not absolutely needed to play, they're just for fun. One of my favorite parts of the game is that there is no end. Dota 2 isn't you made it past level 2, now go to level 3. You progress through the game by understanding and knowledge. Another huge plus is that it gives so many practice opportunities. From the training mode helping you learn mechanics of the game like last hits, to letting you practice your favorite heroes in bot matches. Lastly, the heroes themselves. All of them have their own twist one the game, and their own backgrounds. They have names that stick like Outworld Devourer and Razor. If they were just called mage or brute, it would sound like it would just be another spell-casting, strategic war game. But this is no war game, this is DOTA 2.

review: Pros: - Huge variety of heroes (More heroes are being added) - All heroes are unlocked from the start - Friendly Community - Doesn't need a huge or expensive graphics card, thus any person with a good/decent rig can play the game - Can be played offline by playing with bots or using LAN - Game is free to play - Continuous updates for the game are being done - Well improved graphics than Dota 1 - Doesn't get boring or repetitive due to the diverse amount of heroes and the time it takes to perfect every hero. - Perfects everything that was done in Dota 1 Cons: - Game is addictive - A decent internet speed is required due to constant updates and to play the game without any lags. - Time consuming (An average match takes about 40-35 minutes) Verdict: 9.5/10

game-hours: 1076.9
review: All right, goddammit, I admit defeat. Dota 2 is a huge game that takes place on one map that allows for many playstyles and strategies to flourish. The best part of the game are the holiday modes, which don't involve getting ed in the face by some dork who has played this game for way too long (mostly). Speaking of dorks, this game has a terrible ing community full of ragequitters, brats, tryhards, and dorks. Unfortunately Valve put in a system that allows people to commend or report other people, so griefing is not as painless and boy that won't be abused at all! Overall not very user friendly (especially for newbies) and actually a bit of a pain to play in regards to developing a playstyle, but don't let it shun you, because this game actually may get you to like MOBAs. I ing hated them and now look at me, talking excitedly about how I ganked an Invoker at Mid so I could level up Dagon to Level 3 and then OH MY GOD I AM THE ONE WHO SMELLS LIKE OLD MEAT NOW.

review: DOTA 2 is a simple tower defense game, with a huge number of unique hero options that give the game great depth and variability! I have never had so much fun with a FREE game! Then here are only like 150 other heros to master after that....
game-hours: 696.7
review: Nothing to say. 5 years playing dota 1 n dota 2. This game is my life.
game-hours: 885.4
review: DOTA 2 is a highly strategic-teamwork-heavy game where the objective is to infilitrate the enemy base and destroy their ancient, but there are towers defending the base aswell as enemies. You must level up, gain gold and purchase items to upgrade your character to compete with the 5 players on the other team. There is a very very vaste variety of heroes to choose from, it is recommended that you play them all, to know their weaknesses, strengths and just for fun! It's a little confusing at first, but it's a blast once you get some friends to play with, a mic, and some practice. I highly recommend downloading this FREE game if you are looking for a strategic game that requires teamwork. If you have alot of free time, this game is great, because a single game can take 25 min to 1.5 hours!

review: Dota 2 is a great game. I love it but it's not for everyone. Don't take this the wrong way because it's awesome but you shouldn't play this if you don't want to get screamed at or scream yourself. Everyone in Dota thinks that they know best and some times they do but if you screw up just once (because once is all it takes to loose in Dota) they will tear you a new one before you can apologize. Repentence for this treatment you are given a great moba which is sooooo much better than lol. You actually have to work as a team and everyone matters. The game is won and lost by your very actions. It's great and competitive and super fun. It looks nice and runs nice, it just takes some practice to get good at. Once you are good or atleast reasonable you can just sit back and enjoy (I'm not saying you won't rage at noobs or your own mistakes). 15/15 acing it everyday. Thats Dota 2!

game-hours: 1421.4
review: Possibly the only F2P game that relies solely on skill to win. If you are a new player, I must warn you that this is not JUST A GAME. It is a sport. Obvioulsy, you need to invest time into it because it is so competitve. Time not only playing the game, but also reading guides and watching pro games to help you learn faster. Very few online games out there have you play with 9 other people like this game does. In MMO's you raid one big boss together - basically spam you abilities to take the beast out with minimal communication. In Counter Strike, communication is important but as far as your opponent players go, they're just points (heads) on the screen that you need to shoot before they do. In DotA 2, the enemy heroes are a lot more than just points and the objective(s) is not to get the most kills. People say the community is bad and this is probably the biggest argument there is against this game. Like I always do to players that I don't understand, or if I think they don't know what they're talking about, I just mute them. You can also report bad players and push them into Low Priority. So the game does enough to help reduce your frustration. This is the best game I have ever played. Thank you volvo for making this possible :)

game-hours: 1574.7
review: Dota 2 is easily my favorite moba, and one of my favorite games of all time. The game may be hard to pick up at first, but after you figure out the basics, Dota 2 becomes an addiction. Dota 2 has you striving to be a better player every game you play, even if it's learning a something simple like stacking jungle creeps, you are constantly trying to pick up something new that you can use in future games. Although you will find a surprising amount of aggressive "teammates" who pick on other teammates and can't admit to their own mistakes, it won't stop you from playing. The Dota 2 shop is always being stocked with new cosmetics to buy for your favorite hero, or if you like your chances, you can buy a chest and hope for a rare set or the set that you fancy the most. The game itself gets a steady stream of updates that keeps the game fresh and can change how a hero is best played entirely. All in all, Dota 2 is an amazing game that I recommend anyone should get and atleast give it a shot.

game-hours: 2125.8
review: DotA 2 is a MOBA with a large community following! IM sure you have all seen some kind of gameplay whether it be on youtube or anything else. This game sucks for the first 25 hours if you havent played another MOBA style game, beause there are SO many features and skills you have to learn! but I assure you, the first hours of pain are worth the following thousands to come! I have been playing this game on and off for about two years now, as my first MOBA apart from a brief introduction to the WoW DotA. I love it and have tried several MOBA'S since, such as LoL and HoN but never really got into them. DotA 2 has the same old valve skins system where you can buy cosmetic items for your heroes, ranging from a few cents to hundreds of dollars. However unlike LoL you do not need to pay for any hero or in game feature as it is completely FREE! I reccomend picking this game up and sticking to it until you get the hang of it as it is surely worth it. The community in DotA is like what you would expect in any other online game, you get the good and the bad. Hope this helped! 8/10

game-hours: 398.2
review: At first I thought that MOBAs in general were terrible, I played the DOTA 2 tutorial and played ten matches then uninstalled the game. I really didnt like playing the game because every time I played I was shouted at and put in low priority. About a year later after my friends insisted that I play I started afresh and managed to quickly find my feet and DOTA 2 is now one of my favourite all time games. The steep learning curve makes DOTA 2 hard to get into but after you start understanding tactics and mastering characters it becomes an amazing game. The hundreds of characters, items, playstyles, etc. make every game fresh and exciting. If you manage to make your way out of the (noob/pinoy) bracket of players then suddenly the game opens up with possibilities and becomes one of the best games that I have ever played. It will keep you entertained for years and years.

game-hours: 584.4
review: NICE
game-hours: 332.5
review: Dota 2 has a rather large learning curve but don't let that put you off. You can start by playing against increasingly difficult bots and then play against other people. If you're new, the game will rank you against players with a similar skill level. Finding a group of friends to play with will really enhance the learning process and give you some good laughs. The game itself is incredibly fun and there is always more to learn. Not only is the game free to play but all the heroes are too. The only items which cost any moeny are optional cosmetic items. The community can be unforgiving at times, however the game allows you to mute other players and lets you communicate via a series of informative 'pings' if you so choose. Anyone who is really offensive can be reported for their behaviour. If you are looking for a game to play long-term, where you can have fun with friends but equally, see your time pay off with definite increases in your skill level, then this is for you. Go on, give it a go!

review: So... DotA....Ive had my share of WC3 version of this game (and it rocked my world back then!), so i decided to try and get my invite. After a while i got one and what i saw after installation WAS AMASING! Valve's desingners and artists did their best to bring good old Defense of the Ancients up to the standarts of graphics and style of games today. I will not compare D2 to any other MOBA-game, because itll just cause some disturbance and trolling in the comments section. So lets compare it to the original: graphics(all of it inc. animation and artwork) got better, interface got free from the "chains" of WC3 engine and became more user-friendly, after a while adequate matchmaking system(kind of...), ability to watch tournaments online in client itself, genious marketing model(you can buy ONLY cosmetic items, which will have no impact on balance(HEYO~ other MOBAs! sry..). After a couple of matches i got one thing perfectly clear: DotA2 gives you is thing that youll hate or love, dont think something in-between is possible. Conclusion: MOBA at its finest. Perfect solution to nothing-to-do situation!

game-hours: 16.4
review: I am going to face the consequences of not agreeing with thousands of satisfied gamers, but unfortunately I really can't say I would recommend Dota to anyone. When I was playing the Warcraft 3 mod I was so excited to know that someone was planning to create a whole new game with it (alot of years, accounts, pcs ago...) that I started playing it as soon as it was possible. After some years here I am again, and unfortunately I have to say that I am very disappointed with this game. We know of the awful community, we know of the slow paced mechanics (which may even be a perk for someone), but we can't really accept in this era, an outdated graphic, a really unfriendly interface, and the feeling of general polish lackness that we would expect from a game of this height. Talking from my graphic knowledge, the purity of a well rendered game is to be shown when all the FFXAA postprocessing is off. We clear the bloom, we clear the lightnings, we clear fogs, shinings, reflections, and the core grafic of this game is (in comparison of doing the same with other similar games) so outdated that a tear of nostalgy dropped from my eye, as I was sure I was playing Warcraft. But it's not Warcraft in the far 2002, it's 2015, and we can't really accept such poligonal scarsity and approximative physics. And if you think that I am just asking too much, well, the fact would not be a trouble for me, if it would not give the game an awful, outdated look: not vintage, not nostalgic, just... old. A word should be spent for the well known trouble of the toxic community. If some kind of community, broadly talking, is harassed and worsened by a group of troublemakers, it's imperative that the leaders of the said community do something to resolve the problem ...but no real solutions are being taken. Bans, low priority queues, and such easy going methods probably just worsened the issue, giving the toxic part of the community not a direct message. This could translate as following: if the toxicity of a part of the community is such alarming, and you should care about this trouble, and you can't, well or you are unable to fix it, or you in the end are happy with this (which option I don't know is the worse). Taken singularly Dota 2 is a real game experience that every gamer should do, maybe just for some hours, but putting Dota2 in relation with its most famous counterparts (League of Legends and Heroes of the Storm, to say two names), I am sad to say that my favourite moba looks like the unlucky little brother. Unfortunately this issues can't be closed by a "it's just a matter of tastes" statement: to play this game, and to be happy playing it, we need to fix some technical facts, which the most important are the followings: - a total graphic update, from maps, to buildings, to clutters to (PLEASE) champions; - new physics (never heard of motion capture?), because for freak sake champions move like monsters in Warcraft 3; - a decent interface, both in and off game; - a capital solution for the (broadening) toxicity of the community, because if I wanted to play just with bots in some sort of solo, I'd play GTA, Skyrim, or Dungeon Keeper (always wonderful). To be brutally honest, playing Dota is like finally going out for a drink with your crush, but the beer is awful, there is a terrible karaoke playing at like 3 yards from your table, the food is rancid and the waitress kicks you in the balls because you look like her cheating ex boyfriend. Could be a wonderful experience, but too many things go wrong, and they ruin it. 6,5/10: play it, but there is much better around nowadays.

And with that I set out to do battle, armed with "putang ina mo", "bobo" and many other deadly weapons to do battle with 9 other people, both against you and with you, each armed with their own arsenal of "bodoh", "noob" and in depth knowledge of everyone's families. Even if you lose, it is sometimes still satisfying to engage in a war of insults in multiple languages. Could've learned a musical instrument, a new language, helped poor people, fight for feminism but no. My cardboard box is ready for me. 10/10 would answer Dondo's call again

review: Awesome "MOBA" game that it's prior version sparked the growth of MOBA's in general. DOTA was a mod for Warcraft 3 and soon became a major reason for the purchase of that game. Dota 2 is a standalone that has better graphics and is still being updated with new heroes from the old game and with new game modes. It is fun for new people to try out since there is a tutorial system that teaches you the basics of the game. Plus they also added a coaching system where you can directly talk with your coach during a game to learn things from them. Very awesome game and it is free to play, so good reason to try out. Graphics: 9 - Awesome graphics especially going from the original mod Sound: 9 - Great sound Gameplay: 9.5 - Great gameplay, need so much awareness Story: No story

game-hours: 5398.8
review: Started playing DotA back in 2004 on the War3 platform. Dota 2 is in my opinon the logical progression, bypassing the limitations of the old War3 platform and while it may take a while to learn, the game never gets old. I've played tens of thousands of Dota games (DotA and Dota 2 included) and it's one of those rare few games (across all genres and plaforms) that always keeps you wanting more. I haven't tried the other MOBAs such as LoL and HoN, and to be honest I don't think I will as Dota (being the original MOBA) has more than enough to stop you from wanting to try other MOBA-type games. Some of the most fun times I've had was Dota LAN 10-man all-nighters, with friends pawning each other relentlessly and laughing all the way.

game-hours: 742.2
review: This game waste's alot of hours in alot of peoples lives :P that being said let's get started on the review Gameplsy 8/10 this is a good game, don't get me wrong but it isn't for everyone. it has a pretty high learning curve and takes alot to get used to, that being said, once you are done with the learning curve you will begin to become addicted. Now firstly this game is a MOBA ( Multiplayer online battle arena) in which 2 teams (5v5) go against eachother to defeat eachothers ancients (hence the name, Defence of the Ancients) xD It is quite simple when put that way, but there are many factors that have to be put into place when playing, teammate postioning, attack timing, last hitting etc. I would have given it a bit of a higher rating however there are alot of flamers in the game Who do bad and blame it on everyone else. this is kinda a game ruiner when 3 people in a party begin to blame there team for not helping. But a simple mute can fix that :P Story 2/10 Being a MOBA this game has no story, just an objective to take out the enemy's ancient. Each character may have his/her own backstory but that is not game related. Graphics 7/10 the graphics in dota are quite nice xD Well I particularly like them. Other people might say differently but compared to alot of MOBA's out there Dota has pretty high standards. Overall 8/10 If you can get over the people that whine and the steep learning curve, then you my freind are in for a treat.

game-hours: 274.3
review: My Review for Dota 2. I have had the the pleasure of playing Dota 2, with over 100 games played, and I feel confident enough to write a review for the game. I am still, however, considered painfully new to the Moba scene, and Dota 2 in the grand scheme of things. What is a Moba When I first heard of Mobas in the video game realm after my 20+ years in experience in working, playing, and experiencing video games, I thought... Moba... what is that? With more reading and research the genre seemed like something foreign. RTS' are moving into the not control many units like in Warcraft/starcraft days of old, instead Dota 2 seems to be more of a single hero arena style where farming for resources (or gold) are still an objective to 'unlock' units or (gear in this case) to make your hero more powerful. After hearing younger generations rant on about this game, and the qualities it held, a group of buddies and I, upgraded our computers, and decided it was time to try our hands at Dota. (Specifically Dota 2). Graphics What I have experienced so far is that Dota 2 sets itself apart with continuous updates to the Heroes abilities, which makes the plethora of Heros at the selection and more diversified Hero customization almost unfathomable and a little overwhelming. For such a simple game the graphics are better than what I remember Frozen Throne (WC3), or even Starcraft brood wars. Controls The refined control, and almost seemingly immersive gameplay makes my wife cringe as I boot up my computer, and she hears the famous music from the Dota 2 screen. Shortly after I am ranting, raving, laughing, and sometimes shamefully yelling like I am watching a football game. I enjoy immensely the almost fluid button control off the bat that allows for easy pick up and memorization. Community & Experience The experience that Dota 2 delivers is massive, and the knowledge that is acquired can only be learned through playing matches. This brings me to the Moba community; outwardly the community has an appearance of that of a trojan phalanx. However if you tap into the forums, with Steam (Valves) built in community it can be easy. There can be a rough and jarring experience. The jarring part of the community comes from a small group of people called smurfs whom remake an account and start fresh for better rep, and commending good behavior. These smurfs are seasoned to veteran players who generally play in the beginner matchmaking ranks that prevent most learning from occurring to boost their rep/win/loss ratio. Justice I mentioned commending behavior, this is probably my most favorite tool. Dota 2 has the most effective team that cares to respond to commending, and reporting. The Commending and Reporting system in Dota 2 is like justice from the community, so many dings and you will get punished or banned from the game by the moderators. Commendations occur when people check out your profile and critique the good and bad aspects of your game performances. The four categories to rate people are: Friendly, Forgiving, Teaching, or Leadership. For example, I am not a forgiving teacher, nor am I very forgiving of mistakes so I have 2 Friendly, 0 Forgiving, 1 Teaching, 2 Leadership from community commendations. Coaching Coaches in the Dota2 community are generally a seasoned player that either you come across after failing so many times, or just by simply posting on the Dota 2 community forums and asking for some help. As long as you are polite, and not rude, the community will embrace you, and there are some that would probably embrace you for not. Because the community is massive over 9,000,000 unique hits the month of Dec 2014. In closing, it is almost impossible to cover everything for this game as it is seemingly simplistic and very in depth at the same time. Because of the experience in this game is Community based I factored that into my judgement. Rating:4/5 Pros: Graphics Hero Selection Commending/Reporting Refined Controls Continually updated Coaching Cons: Community- outward appearance perception is everything Hero Customization- can be overwhelming at first

review: Honest Review. This game is a huge headache Ive been playing MOBA's for over 12 years. You want to progress without a team. Prepare to be at the fate of people that do not want to play as a team game. This game is meant to be a team game. The Team idea of this game is for your entire team to pick a ( Carry ) most cases a hero that can last the length of a game and skills scale very well. Hence everyone wanting to play this type of hero. Then you have support which I really do not mind playing as well as long as we are a team. Nope be prepared to be faustrated to the point of no return. I have uninstalled this game as I can truly see no positive coming from this game. People are rude. The team play is near non existent unless you are on a team and everyone wants to have the score despite no record keeping being held on the game. Yes it is easier to potty train your children then to progress past a point in this game. Then if you make mistakes instead of being coached you get bashed on continuesly until your spirit is not even in the game no more. Yes Potty training is not fun, but at least your kids arent bashing you continuesly while your coaching them to aim their skills correctly. Soapbox out and I've uninstalled this trainwreck for the last time. Thank you valve for bringing premium entertainment at no cost but I think I would rather be in the bathroom at this point at least everyone there speaks english. Edit 12/24/2014. The matchmaking is tons better most of the time you get a team that wants to win but on occaision it can be a drain to be in a game.

review: Overview: Dota 2 is hands down one of the most challenging games to get in to, the sheer amount of items, heroes, and mechanics can seem extremely overwhelming. But don't let this discourage you! As one grits their teeth and pushes through, they will discover a game rich in content and a game that is very enjoyable to play. Dota 2 has been one of the most challenging games I have ever played and I find myself drawn back to it often for that very reason. This game is not only fun, but very satisfying to play, esspecially in the team setting. What I would like to see...: Despite the recently implemented tutorials, the experience for new players can still be very rough, I would like to see a more community based introduction to help new players. In addition to this, I feel like the games interface is filled with hidden bugs that often get ignored in favor of ballance fixes, let's see some client fixes! Bottom Line: If you want a challenge and can invest some time, download Dota 2. If you are looking to get into this game but are confused by the game, message me, and I will help you. I love this game! Kanoobee's Score: 9/10

review: The most engrossing game I have ever played. I started playing the game thinking that I probably wouldn't like it and would stop after a game or two. 300+ hours later here I am, still improving and still learning all the subtleties of the game that only experience can give you. A very steep learning curve requires you to play several games before you can even get the basic mechanics down, not to mention the hours it will take to learn the nuances of all the heroes and items, and how they interact with each other. Once you can get past the initial wall, it is a game that can be played for hours on end, and doesn't seem to have an end in sight, as it's gameplay seemingly will carry on years into the future. Plus it's free, so why not?

review: It's been almost 6 years now since i was introduced to Dota. Dota is a game that i can play without getting bored just because there are over a hundred heroes to try out and to master. Until now i still have not mastered all of them. Dota is a very strategy dependent game, it requires quite a lot of logic and quick reaction. Playing with friends in a match making system as a team of 5 or creating a custom game where you can play 5vs5 with your friends are both addictive. I was so excited when Dota2 finally came out as i was a big fan of Dota originally. So far i have been experiencing the magical world of Dota2. The only problem i seem to have is i can never find enough people to fill up the 4th or the 5th slot when finding a match because people are just so busy nowadays. I therefore strongly encourage you guys to play Dota2. It is free to play and especialy fun to play with friends. So why don't you download it now?! (PL: Don't worry beginners, Dota2 provides you with a lot of training before the war commence!)

game-hours: 114.3
review: Eh, It's alright. Community is toxic, though. Okay, but in all seriousness: DotA 2 is a good game. It's challenging, strategic and fun. The major complaint I have with this game is that it's made by VALVe. NOW LET ME EXPLAIN: I love VALVe, and I love their games. But VALVe has stuck with the First-person genre for a really long time, and I'm not too sure they should go to the MOBA genre. For one, when you are playing their games, you can see and feel how much effort they've put into the scenery and textures, no matter what game (Yes, I know some of the Textures in HL2 were , but it was 2004, guys, come on.) In DotA, on the other hand, the whole enviroment looks really bland and boring to me. You hardly notice the amount of effort put into texures in this game, and boy, is it minimal. I mean, sure, it's fine, but it doesn't live up to VALVe standards. Which brings me to another subject: The Characters. VALVe games also have interesting characters with fun and loveable personalities. For example: GLaDOS's sarcastic and sadistic personality, Francis's tough and douchy personality and Soldier's patriotic and kinda dumb personality. In DotA...None of the charaters have much personality... I mean, sure, they do say some funny things now and then, but to me, they're like cardboard with a little rainbow paint in the middle: It doesn't stick out that much, and they feel really bland, something that isn't quite VALVe-ish. And you can make the arguement that: ''Oh, but they had to cut down the personality-thingies because of the abilities!'' Yes, I know that, but I wouldn't say that anyone's abilities are that thought out (Except for Invoker's.) Don't get me wrong, there must've been some planning, but just by looking at the Models, you can kinda feel what this hero's abilites are. FOr example: Huskar, just by looking at him, I can tell that he's a berserker, and his abilities focus around that: The more he is damaged, the more he hits. And that's the thing! They put more time into the moveset than the actual characters, and that's something that really bothers me... But yeah, I do recommend this game. It's still fun, but if you're a diehard fan of VALVe, I think you should stear away from it, and find out what you're getting into: This is NOT a regular VALVe game.

game-hours: 1371.9

game-hours: 743.4
review: Awesome game :)
game-hours: 706.9
review: This game... This game is so much fun. I had never played a MOBA before Dota 2, and I thought I never would. If you didn't know what a MOBA was, it's a Multiplayer Online Battle Arena. There are 10 people in a game, 5 on each team. You pick a hero out of 100+ heroes and fight together as a team and hopefully win. It sounds straight forward, but there is a lot of strategy involved and you have to think before you act. I remember hearing about it a lot while it was in Beta, but never really took an interest in it. But when it officially realized, I took a stab at it and never look back. I now have about 140 hours on it, and I've been playing it for a couple months. It is that fun. But if you have never played a MOBA before, it has a VERY steep learning curve. I remember going into my first online game after the training and was for some reason in the All Pick gamemode (I'll get to the gamemodes later) for some reason and played as Bristleback as he look really awesome. I though I would do good... I was wrong, so wrong. I did sooooo bad, so, so bad. I recommend you look up some guides and videos before you jump into online. Also, play a lot of bot games before online too. When you start playing online, choose the Limited Heroes mode. The LM mode is where you can choose out of the 20 easiest heroes and hopefully play against other new people. This is where everyone should start. The other gamemodes are Single Draft, you choose out of 3 randomly chosen heroes, Least Played, you can choose out of your leasted played heroes, All Pick, where you can choose any hero, Captains Draft, you get assigned a captain who assigns and bans heroes for you from a limited hero pool, Captains Mode, the same as Captains Draft, but you can pick and ban all the heroes in the game, not just some, Random Draft, you choose a hero out of a pool of 20 heroes, everyone takes turns, and All Random, you get assigned a random hero. Dota 2 is a free to play game, but it is NOT pay to win. Everything you can buy are all cosmetic and do not affect gameplay. When you are in your match, there will be things called "Towers", you want to protect yours and destroy the other teams. There are also little minions called Creeps, they are more important than you think. They go up with you in the Lanes, which there are 3 of. A bottom, middle, and top lane. Your prized possesion and most valuable structure is your Ancient. If you destroy the other teams, you win, if they destroy yours, you lose. Simple. There is also a big monseter called Roshan. If you kill him, he drops an item call the Aegis of the Immortal. Whoever picks it up will resurrect at the spot they died. There is some more in depth stuff in the game, but this is a review, not a guide. So there it is. my review for Dota 2. It is a very, very fun and addicting MOBA with a steep learning curve. if you just want a score, I would give it a 9.5/10. Not a 10 because of it's steep learning curve preventing some players getting into the game. Thanks for reading! :) Also, this was my first Steam review, feed back is appreciated.

game-hours: 199.6
review: Dota 2 is a game that is horrific at first but gradually gets better more you play. The main thing that makes Dota 2 a good game is the equality of classes. There are around 30 different people that you can choose to be before starting a game and most of them are as good a choice of being the other as they will all have posotives and negatives attatched to each class. Some classes are better at the start of the game and some at the end. The ones better at the start of the game are called supports and the ones at the end are called carries. There are 3 categories that classes are placed in: agility, intelligence and stamina. Each game lasts approxtimately 30 to 50 mins but occasionally over/under. There are 2 teams of 5 (named Radiant and Dire)and as the game progresses, characters are leveled up by killing al controlled creeps or other heroes or neutrals or runes. I wont explain what any of these are as this is a review not an explanation. There are 2 major problems with Dota 2 and they are firstly there is only one map. The map has been designed to be even and fair but it can get boring after a while. If you leave a match or get reported a certain amount of times then you will get put into low priority meaning that you can only play with other people that leave the match until you get rid of your 'abandons.' This punishment is beneficial for players that constantly play it as it can get annoying if you lose a match because someone quit however for people that have to go when they have to go it can be unfair because they get penalised a lot and after all it is only a game and it isn't really fair to penalise someone when they are meant to be haing fun. Anyway, the second thing that so many people CANT STAND is the wait. The most I have waited for a match is 20 mins and at the least it takes around 7 mins to find a game and this is all down to slow running servers. You will have to wait around 1 min to join a game on Advanced Warfare PS4 eddition to put this in contrast. This wasted time does build up and you may eventualy find yourself thinking what's the point. Having said this, there are only 2 or 3 (depending whether you are a sweat or not) main negatives for this game and so many other games have so much more faults. I hope you found this useful. Please comment and bye. TCM

review: It is really hard to write a review about a game that I love yet brings such rage and anger to me. Obviously this is the same concept as LoL and it has the same gameplay formula. It has it's positives and it's negatives. I have found that a few positives are that the characters are varied and somewhat interesting and their backstories always seem like a good read, it also does not force you to pay for characters to play them such as LoL or Smite, there are no items that the community can buy for their characters that offer bonuses when bought outside the game. They are purely cosmetic, so if you want your character to look nicer then that is there for you. Now I hate to write negatives about games that I actually enjoy but this is a personal peeve of mine. I want to play with people in East or West Europe? That's fine I don't mind meeeting them. Another thing that really grinds me is when the servers can connect you into the game and you can go for a good ten or twenty or even 30 minutes playing with no problem and then get a disconnect from server. That brings my blood to a boil and I find this happening a hell of a lot more every day and I get that it is the Year of the Beast Brawl and that is going to be heavily populated, but why the hell should that affect mine and other Dota player's experience? I am going to say that it needs to be fixed or I am just going to have to stop playing this game and I would hate to do that.

game-hours: 70.6
review: its nice
game-hours: 914.6
review: Been playing DotA since WarCraft 3 age. Why choose DotA over LoL? Here's why! Some of these things may actually interest you; that's cool, you deserve to be playing LoL then. But for the rest of us that actually enjoy the game, the lore, and have the skill, we deserve DotA2. DotA came before LoL; in fact, some original blokes that worked on DotA moved on to create LoL (Because let's make money). LoL certainly had a "time induced factor" on their side. But DotA, coming from its WC3 roots, brought the game into a new era. So everything that LoL got wrong, DotA2 got right. It may come as a personal preference, but DotA 2 doesn't have the out-of-game, gameplay-breaking factors that is Runes and Mastery pages. One of the major enjoyments about engagements is calculations on the fly - when you've become great at the game, you can compute on the fly if you're going to land this 1 v 1 kill or not. Walking away with the win with less than 50 HP left will screw with the opponents mindset. In LoL, you can't calculate anything like that since you don't know people's runes or masteries. Certainly you can use some websites that are suppose to show those to you, but that is just one flaw in a game - you shouldn't have to be windowing out/checking second monitor. Oh yeah, playing level 10 with almost no runes vs someone with same hero, level 30 rune page with everything unlocked. No matter your skills, you will lose. How is that fair? --- The major complaint about runes/masteries; if you pick up the wrong one due to "lag" at 'loading screen' your game is officially ruined --- Unlike LoL, if your carry sucks you can still effectively carry the game as just a support hero. There are limits to this, such as what heros the enemy team picked vs yours. There's a reason why Silencer was labeled as a carry. If my team is doing trash, I/you can easily turn the game around and win with Shadow Shaman or a Disruptor. In LoL, you think you'll carry with a Soraka? Get out of here... With that note, feeders - unlike LoL, you can win the game even on the rare occassion you get some whiny feeder that didn't get their lane - One of my gameplay recaps was us winning a game even though our ES went full  0-25 because he couldn't handle constructive criticism. Further tac-on; disruptive players can end up muted or in low priority matches. Verbal abuse is punished. Those that fed and/or leave games constantly get put in low priority. For the most part, the DotA community is self-regulated not to be like LoLers - LoL will report for anything, and whine constantly. COSMETICS! This may seem like a minor footnote to people, but it shouldn't! If you're going to want to play a game constantly, why not have some degree on the way the game plays and looks to you? Starting with LoL: you buy a skin that effectively changes the entire outlook/skill use design of the hero. In DotA2, you can customize everything; Don't like the complete set? Change out the chest piece from a different set. Make it completely random! It comes to a point that your hero will not look the same as any other hero out there. Exceptions would be the Arcana set - but even then that is one item piece. And lets just say, Legion Commanders Arcana will change the "look" of all the other pieces she is wearing. B. There is no free town scrolls here. LoL seems to encourage bad plays/get out of jail free. In Dota2, it'll cost you 100gold, no biggie right? If you're constantly going back to fountain, not only are you being hurt by exp loss, but a gold loss as well. This makes the game more exciting, a cat and mouse chase looking for that hero that is almost dead. You'll get the joy and satisfaction of finding that scrub or being that guy that juked them all and got away like a boss. LoL you just press B in a bush. How borring. You can't spamy spam hero skills. This makes precise timing important and game changing. You have a limited mana pool at start and need to be intelligent about what you're doing. LoL, you can spam away all game, if you wanted. That doesn't take skill and isn't very rewarding. In LoL, it's designed for the support to poke a hero to near death and hope your carry is intelligent enough to engage before they just press B and get back to the fountain for free. Summoner spells! Get the hell out of here with that crap. DotA2 doesn't have any of that , thank god. Voice chat. It wouldn't work in LoL because of the teenage ragers, so they don't have it. DotA 2 has it, and it helps tremendously. If you're a LoL player, try dota out. Play against bots to begin, learn the gameplay/heroes. Form friendships - you'll see why DotA2 was designed with a higher quality than LoL. Did I forget anything? Maybe. Hopefully I can edit if I recall anything. RECAP! + DotA been around for a long time (Lore, thoughtful gameplay, etc) + No Rune/Masteries + Crap carries doesn't mean the game is lost + Honest reporting/banning + Cosmetic items that makes LoL look like a cheap flea market + Everything, including time, comes with a price. Use wisely + No spammy spam spells + No Summoner spells (Thank.... God!) + Voice chat + The Bunny Says So!
